editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: BEN: IONSON, HIS CASE IS ALTERD.
As it hath beene ſundry times Acted by the Children of Blacke-friers.
AT LONDON Printed for Bartholomew Sutton, dwelling in Paules Church-yard neere the great north doore of S. Paules Church. 1609.

div.head: A pleaſant Comedy called, the Caſe is Alterd.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Sound? after a flouriſh: Iuniper a Cobler is diſcouered, ſitting at worke in his ſhoppe and ſinging.

sp.speaker: Iuniper, Onion, Antony Baladino.
sp.l: YOV wofull wights giue eare a while,

l.hi: And marke the tenor of my ſtile,
Which ſhall ſuch trembling hearts vnfold
As ſeldome hath to fore bene told.
Such chances rare and dolefull newes

sp.l: Peace a Gods name.

l.hi: As may attempt your wits to muſe.

sp.l: A pox a God on you.

l.hi: And cauſe ſuch trickling teares to paſſe,
Except your hearts be flint or braſſe:

sp.l: To heare the newes which I ſhall tell,
That in Caſtella once befell.
Sbloud, where didſt thou learne to corrupt a man in the midſt of a verſe, ha?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Gods lid man, ſeruice is ready to go vp man, you muſt ſlip on your coate and come in, we lacke waiters pittyfully.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: A pittifull hearing, for now muſt I of a merry Cobler become mourning creature.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Well youle come.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Preſto. Go to, a word to the wiſe, away, flie? vaniſh: Lye there the weedes that I diſdaine to weare.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: God ſaue you Maiſter Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What Signior Antonio Balladino, welcome ſweet Ingle,

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And how do you ſir?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Faith you ſee, put to my ſhifts here as poore retainers be oftentimes, ſirrah Antony ther's one of my fellowes mightely enamored of thee, and I faith you ſlaue, now your come I'le bring you together, i'ts Peter Onion, the groome of the hal, do you know him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No not yet, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O he is one as right of thy humour as may be, a plaine ſimple Raſcal, a true dunce, marry he hath bene anotable vilaine in his time: he is in loue, ſirrah, with awench, & I haue preferd thee to him, thou ſhalt make him ſome prety Paradox or ſome Aligory, how does my coate ſit? well.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I very well.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Na Gods ſo, fellow Iuniper, come away.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Art thou there mad ſlaue, I come with a powder?. Sirrah fellow Onion. I muſt haue you peruſe this Gentleman well, and doe him good offices of reſpect and kindneſſe, as inſtance ſhall be giuen.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Nay good maiſter Onion what do you meane, I pray you ſir you are to reſpectue in good faith.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I would not you ſhould thinke ſo ſir, for though I haue no learning, yet I honour a ſcholer in any ground of the earth ſir,
Shall I requeſt your name ſir?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My name is Antonio Balladino.

sp.speaker: Oni,
sp.p: Balladino? you are not Pageant Poet to the City of Millaine ſir▪ are you.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I ſupply the place ſir: when aworſe cannot be had ſir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I crie you mercy ſir, I loue you the better for that ſir, by Ieſu you muſt pardon me, I knew you not, but Il'd pray to be better acquainted with you ſir, I haue ſeene of your works.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I am at your ſeruice good Maiſter Onion, but concerning this maiden that you loue ſir? what is ſhe,

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p:
O did my fellow Iuniper tell you? marry ſir, ſhe is
as one may ſay, but a poore mans child indeede, and for mine owne part I am no Gentleman borne I muſt confeſſe, but my mind to me a kingdome is truly.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Truly a very good ſaying.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: T'is ſomewhat ſtale, but that's no matter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: O t'is the better, ſuch things euer are like bread, which the ſtaler it is, the more holeſome.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: This is but a hungry compariſon in my iudgement.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell you, M. Onion, I do vſe as much ſtale ſtuffe, though I ſay it my ſelfe, as any man does in that kind I am ſure. Did you ſee the laſt Pageant, I ſet forth?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: No faith ſir, but there goes a huge report on't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, you ſhal be one of my Maecen-aſſes, I'le giue you one of the bookes, O you'le like it admirably.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay that's certaine, I'le get my fellow Iuniper to read it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Reade it ſir, I'le reade it to you.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Tut then I ſhall not chuſe but like it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why looke you ſir, I write ſo plaine, and keepe that old Decorum, that you muſt of neceſſitie like it; mary you ſhall haue ſome now (as for example, in plaies) that will haue euery day new trickes, and write you nothing but humours: indeede this pleaſes the Gentlemen: but the common ſort they care not for't, they know not what to make on't, they looke for good matter, they, and are not edified with ſuch toyes.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: You are in the right, I'le not giue a halfepeny to ſee a thouſand on'hem. I was at one the laſt Tearme, but & euer I ſee a more roguiſh thing, I am a peece of cheeſe, & no onion, nothing but kings & princes in it, the foole came not out a lot.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: True ſir, they would haue me make ſuch plaies, but as I tell hem, and they'le giue me twenty pound a play, I'le not raiſe my vaine.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: No, it were a vaine thing, and you ſhould ſir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Tut giue me the penny, giue me the peny, I care not for the Gentlemen I, let me haue a good ground, no matter for the pen the plot ſhall carry it.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p:
Indeed that's right, you are in print already for the
beſt plotter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I, I might as well ha bene put in for a dumb ſhew too.

sp.speaker: Ont.
sp.p: I marry ſir, I marle you were not, ſtand aſide ſir a while:

div.stage: Enter an armd Sewer: ſome halfe dozen in mourning coates following and paſſe by with ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: How now friend, what are you there? be vncouered, Would you ſpeake with any man here?

sp.speaker: Valen,
sp.p: I, or elſe I muſt Ira' returnd you no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Friend, you are ſomewhat to peremptory, let's craue your abſence: nay neuer ſcorne it, I am a little your better in this place.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I do acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Do you acknowledge it? nay then you ſhall go forth, Ile teach you how ſhall acknowledge it another time; go to, void, I muſt haue the hall purg'd, no ſetting vp of a reſt here, packe, begone.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I pray you ſir is not your name Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Your friend as you may vſe him, and M. Onion, ſay on.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: M. Onion with a murraine, come come put off this Lyons hide, your eares haue diſcouered you, why Peter! do not I know you Peter?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Gods ſo, Valentine!

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O can you take knowledge of me now ſir?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Good Lord, ſirra, how thou art altred with thy trauell?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Nothing ſo much as thou art with thine office, but ſirra, Onion is the Count Ferneze at home?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I Bully, he is aboue; and the Lord Paulo Ferneze, his ſon, and Maddam Aurelia, & maddam Phaenixella, his daughters, But O Valentine?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: How now man, how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Faith ſad, heauy, as a man of my coate ought to be.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why man, thou wert merry inough euen now.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: True, but thou knoweſt

l.hi: All creatures here ſoiorning, vpon this wretched earth,
Sometimes haue a fit of mourning, as well as a fit of mirth.

sp.l: O Valentine, mine old Lady is dead, man.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I faith.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: When dyed ſhe?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Mary, to morrow ſhall be three months, ſhe was ſeene going to heauen they ſay, about ſome fiue weekes agone! how now? trickling teares, ha?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith thou haſt made me weepe with this newes.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Faith thou haſt made me weepe with this newes.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Why I haue done but the parte of an Onion, you muſt pardon me.

div.head: Scaene. 2.
div.stage: Enter the ſewer, paſſe by with ſeruice againe, the ſeruing-men take knowledge of Valentine as they goe. Iuniper ſalutes him.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What Valentiue? fellow Onion, take my diſh I prithee you rogue ſirrah, tell me, how thou doſt, ſweet Ingle.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith, Iuniper, the better to ſee thee thus frolicke.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Nay, ſlid I am no changling, I am Iuniper ſtill. Exit Oni. I keepe the priſtmate ha, you mad Hierogliphick, when ſhal we ſwagger.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Hierogliphick, what meaneſt thou by that.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Meane? Gods ſo, iſt not a good word man? what? ſtand vpon meaning with your freinds. Puh, Abſconde.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why, but ſtay, ſtay, how long has this ſprightly humor haunted thee?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Foe humour, a fooliſh naturall gift we haue in the Aequinoctiall.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Naturall, ſlid it may be ſupernaturall, this?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Valentine, I prithee ruminate thy ſelfe welcome. What fortuna de la Guerra.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: O how pittifully are theſe words forc't.
As though they were pumpt out on's belly.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Sirrah Ingle, I thinke thou haſt ſeene all the ſtrange countries in Chriſtendome ſince thou wentſt?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I haue ſeene ſome Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: You haue ſeene Conſtantinople?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I, that I haue.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: And Ieruſalem, and the Indies, and Goodwine ſands, and the tower of Babylon, and Venice and all.

sp.speaker: Valen.
Iuni.
sp.p: O it's a moſt heauenly thing to trauel, & ſee countries, eſpecially at ſea, and a man had a pattent not to be ſicke.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O ſea ſicke leſt, and full of the ſcuruie.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Iuniper, Antonio, Sebaſtian, Martino, Vincentio, Balthaſar and Chriſtophero.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Valentine? welcome I faith how doſt ſirra?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: How do you good Valentine.

sp.speaker: Vincen.
sp.p: Troth, Valentine, I am glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Welcome ſweet rogue.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Before God he neuer lookt better in his life.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: And how iſt man? what, Alla Coragio.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Neuer better gentlemen I faith.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: S'will here comes the ſteward.

sp.speaker: Chriſt.
sp.p: Why how now fellowes all here? and nobody to waight aboue now they are ready to riſe? looke vp one or two Signior Franceſco Colomia's man how doo's your good maiſter.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: In health ſir he will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Chriſto.
sp.p: Is he come home, then?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I ſir he is not paſt ſixe miles hence, he ſent me before to learne if Count Ferneze were here and returne him word.

sp.speaker: Chriſto.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord is here; and you may tel your maiſter he ſhal come very happily to take his leaue of Lord Paulo Ferneze: who is now inſtantly to depart with other noble gentlemen, vpon ſpeciall ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I will tell him ſir.

sp.speaker: Chriſto.
sp.p: I pray you doe, fellowes make him drinke.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Sirs, what ſeruice iſt they are imployed in?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Why againſt the French they meane to haue a fling at Millaine againe they ſay.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Who leades our forces, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Marry that do's Signior Maximilian? he is aboue, now.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Who, Maximilian of Vicenza?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: I he? do you know him?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Know him? O yes he's an excellent braue ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: I ſo they ſay, but one of the moſt vaine glorious men in Europe.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: He is indeed, marry exceeding valient.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: And that is rare.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Why to ſee a vaineglorious man valient.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Well he is ſo I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What no further yet, come on you precious raſcall, ſir Valentine, Ile giue you a health I faith, for the heauens you mad Capriceio, hold hooke and line.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Lord Paulo Ferneze, his boy following him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Sirrah go vp to Signior Angelio,
And pray him (if he can) deuiſe ſome meanes,
To leaue my father, and come ſpeake with me.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Well heauen, be auſpicious in the euent;
For I do this againſt my Genius,
And yet my thoughts cannot propoſe a reaſon.
Why I ſhould feare, or faint thus in my hopes,
Of one ſo much endeered to my loue.
Some ſparke it is, kindled within the ſoule:
Whoſe light yet breaks not to the outward ſence,
That propagates this tymerous ſuſpect;
His actions neuer carried any face
Of change, or weaknes: then I iniury him?
In being thus cold conceited of his faith,
O here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now ſweet Lord, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Good faith his preſence makes me halfe aſhamd.
Of my ſtraid thoughts. Boy. Beſtow your ſelfe.
Where is my father, Signior Angelio.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Marry in the galery, where your Lordſhip left him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Thats well. Then Angelio I will be briefe.
Since time forbids the vſe of circumſtance,
How well you are receiued in my affection,
Let it appeare by this one inſtance, onely
That now I will deliuer to your truſt,
The deereſt ſecrets, treaſurd in my boſome,
Deare Angelio. You are not euery man,
But one, whome my election hath deſign'd,
As the true proper obiect of my ſoule:
I vrge not this t'inſinuate my deſert,
Or ſupple your tri'd temper, with ſoft phraſes;
True frendſhip lothes ſuch oyly complement:
But from th'aboundance of that loue, that flowes
Through all my ſpirits, is my ſpeech enforc'd.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Before your Lordſhip do proceed too far,
Let me be bould to intimate thus much;
That what ſo ere your wiſedome hath t'expoſe,
Be it the waightieſt and moſt rich affaire,
That euer was included in your breaſt,
My faith ſhall poiſe it, if not—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: O no more,
Thoſe words haue rapt me with their ſweet effects,
So freely breath'd, and ſo reſponſible,
To that which I endeuoured to extract,
Arguing a happy mixture of our ſoules.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Why were there no ſuch ſympathy ſweete Lord?
Yet the impreſſure of thoſe ample fauours,
I haue deriu'd from your vnmatched ſpirit,
Would bind my faith to all obſeruances.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: How! fauours Angello, ô ſpeake not of them,
They are meere paintings, and import no merit,
Lookes my loue well? thereon my hopes are plac't:
Faith, that is bought with fauours, cannot laſt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are ſought for all about the houſe, within,
The Count your father cals for you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: God, what croſſe euents do meet my purpoſes?
Now will he violently fret and grieue
That I am abſent. Boy, ſay I come preſently:
Sweet Angello, I cannot now inſiſt
Vpon particulars, I muſt ſerue the time
The maine of all this is, I am in loue.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Why ſtarts your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I thought I heard my father comming hither ward, liſt, ha?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: I heare not any thing, it was but your imagination ſure.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: No, I aſſure your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I would worke ſafely.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Why, has he no knowledge of it then?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: O no, no creature yet pertakes it but your ſelfe
In a third perſon, and beleeue me friend,
The world containes not now another ſpirit,
To whom I would reueile it. Harke, harke,

div.stage: Seruants. Signior Paulo. Lord Ferneze. within.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: A pox vpon thoſe brazen throated ſlaues,
What are they mad, trow?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Alas, blame not them,
Their ſeruices are (clock-like) to beſet,
Backward and forward, at their Lords command,
You know my father's wayward, and his humour
Muſt not receiue a check, for then all obiects,
Feede both his griefe and his impatience,
And thoſe affections in him, are like powder,
Apt to enflame with euery little ſparke,
And blow vp reaſon, therefore Angelo, peace.

div.stage:
within.
Count.
Why this is rare, is he not in the garden?
Criſt.
I know not my Lord.
Count.
See, call him?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: He is comming this way, let's withdraw a little.

div.stage: within. Seruants. Signior Paulo, Lord Ferneze, Lord Paulo.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Count Ferneze, Maximilian, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Sebaſt. Balthaſar.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: VVHere ſhould he be, trow? did you looke in the armory?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, why there? ô who would keepe ſuch drones? Exeunt Sebaſt. and Baltha. How now, ha ye found him?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: No my Lord, I ſhall haue ſhortly all my family
Speake nought, but no my Lord, where is Chriſtophero,
Looke how he ſtands, you ſleep y knaue,
What is he not in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Chriſto.
sp.p: No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your good Lord, ô how this ſmels of fennell. Enter Sebaſt Baltha. You haue bene in the garden it appeares, well, well.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: We cannot find him my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: He is not in the armory.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He is not, he is no where, is he?

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Count Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Preſerue your patience honorable Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Patience? a Saint would looſe his patience to be croſt,
As I am with a ſort of motly braines,
See ſee, how like a neſt of Rookes they ſtand,
Gaping on one another! now Diligence, what news bring you?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ant pleaſe your honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tut, tut, leaue pleaſing of my honour Diligence, you double with we, come.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: How: does he find fault with Pleaſe his Honour. S'wounds it has begun a ſeruing mans ſpeech, euer ſince I belongd to the blew order: I know not how it may ſhew, now I am in blacke, but—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Whats that, you mutter ſir? will you proceed?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ant like your good Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet more; Gods precious.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: What, do not this like him neither?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What ſay you ſir knaue?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Mary I ſay your Lordſhip were beſt to ſet me to ſchoole againe, to learne how to deliuer a meſſage.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What do you take exceptions at me then.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Exception? I take no exceptions, but by Gods ſo your humours—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go to you are a Raskall, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Your Lordſhips poore ſeruant, I.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tempt not my patience.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Why I hope I am no ſpirit, am I?

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: My Lord, command your Steward to correct the ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Correct him, S'bloud come you and correct him and you haue a minde to it, correct him, that's a good ieſt I faith, the Steward and you both, come and correct him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay ſee, away with him, pull his cloth ouer his eares.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Cloth? tell me of your cloth, here's your cloth, nay and I mourne a minute longer, I am the rotteneſt Onion that euer ſpake with a tongue.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: What call your hind's count Ferneze?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: His name is Onion Signior,

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: I thought him ſome ſuch ſawcy companion.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Signior Maximillian.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Let me intreat you, you would not regard
Any contempt flowing from ſuch a ſpirit,
So rude, ſo barbarous.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Moſt noble Count vnder your fauour—

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Why Ile tell you Signior,
Heele bandy with me word for word, nay more,
Put me to ſilence, ſtrike me perfect dumb;
And ſo amaze me, that oftentimes I know not,
Whether to check or cheriſh his preſumption:
Therefore good Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Sweet Lord ſatisfie your ſelfe, I am not now to learn how to manage my affections, I haue obſeru'd, and know the difference betweene a baſe wretch and a true man, I can diſtinguiſh them, the property of the wretch is, he would hurt and cannot, of the man, he can hurt, and will not.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Go to, my merry daughter, ô theſe lookes,
Agree well with your habit, do they not?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Tut, let me alone. By your fauour, this is the Gentleman I thinke, Sir you appeare to be an honorable Gentleman, I vnderſtand, and could wiſh (for mine owne part) that things were conden't otherwiſe then they are: but (the world knowes) a fooliſh fellow, ſomewhat procliue, and haſty, he did it in a preiudicate humour; mary now vpon better computation, he wanes; he melts; his poore eyes are in a cold ſweat. Right noble Signior, you can haue but compunction, I loue the man, tender your compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Doth any man here vnderſtand this fellow?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: O God ſir, I may ſay fruſtra to the comprehenſion of your intellection.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.l: Before the Lord, he ſpeakes all riddle, I thinke.
I muſt haue a comment ere I can conceiue him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Why he ſues to haue his fellow Onion pardon'd,
And you muſt grant it Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: O with all my ſoule my Lord, is that his motion?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: I ſir, and we ſhall retort theſe kinde fauours with all allacrity of ſpirit, we can ſir, as may be moſt expedient, as well for the quality as the cauſe, till when in ſpight of this complement: I reſt a poore Cobler, ſeruant to my honorable Lord here, your friend and Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: How Iuniper?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: He is a ſweete youth, his tongue has a happy turne when he ſleepes.

div.stage: Enter Paulo Ferneze, Franciſco, Colomea, Angelo, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I for then it reſts, O Sir your welcome,
Why God be thanked you are found at laſt.
Signior Coloma truly you are welcome,
I am glad to ſee you ſir ſo well returned.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I gladly thanke your honour, yet indeed
I am ſory for ſuch cauſe of heauineſſe,
As hath poſſeſt your Lordſhip in my abſence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O Franciſco' you knew her what ſhe was!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She was a wiſe and honorable Lady.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I was ſhe not! well weepe not ſhe is gone,
Paſſons duld eye can make two grieues of one,
Whom death marke out, vertue, nor bluod can ſaue,
Princes, as beggers, all muſt feed the graue.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Are your horſe ready Lord Paulo,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I ſignior the ſtay for vs at the gate.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Well tis good. Ladies I will take my leaue of you,
Be your fortunes as your ſelues? faire. Come let vs to horſe,
Count Ferneze I beare a ſpirit full of thanks for all your honorable courteſies.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir I could wiſh the number and value of them more in reſpect of your deſeruings. But Signior Maximillian. I pay you a word in priuate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I Faith brother you are fitted for a generall yonder, Beſhrow my heart (If I had Fortunatus hat here) and I would not wiſh my ſelfe a man and go with you, only t'enioy his preſence.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why do you loue him ſo well ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No by my troth, but I haue ſuch an odde prety apprehenſion of his humour me thinks: that I am eene tickled with the conceite of it.
O he is a fine man.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: And me thinks another may be as fine as he.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O Angelio, do you thinke I do vrge any compariſon againſt you? no, I am not ſo ill bred, as to be a deprauer of your worthines: beleeue me, if I had not ſome hope of your abiding with vs, I ſhould neuer deſire to go out of black whilſt I liued: but learne to ſpeake i'the noſe, and turne puritan preſently.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I thanke you Lady: I know you can flout.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come doe you take it ſo? I faith you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I, but Maddame,
Thus to diſclaime in all the effects of pleaſure,
May make your ſadneſſe ſeeme to much affected,
And then the proper grace of it is loſt.

sp.speaker: Phoenix
sp.l: Indeed ſir, if I did put on this ſadneſſe
Onely abroad, and in Society,
And were in priuate merry; and quick humor'd;
Then might it ſeeme affected and abhord:
But as my lookes appeare, ſuch is my ſpirit,
Drown'd vp with confluence of griefe, and melancholy,
That like to riuers run through all my vaines,
Quenching the pride and feruour of my bloud.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My honorable Lord? no more.
There is the honour of my bloud ingag'd,
For your ſonnes ſafety.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Signior, blame me not,
For tending his ſecurity ſo much,
He is mine onely ſonne, and that word onely,
Hath with his ſtrong, and reprecuſſiue ſound,
Stroke my heart cold, and giuen it a deepe wound.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Why but ſtay, I beſeech you, had your Lordſhip euer any more ſonnes then this.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why haue not you knowen it Maximilian?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Let my Sword faile me then.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I had one other yonger borne then this,
By twiſe ſo many how ers as would fill
The circle of a yeare, his name Camillo,
Whome in that blacke, and fearfull night I loſt,
(Tis now a nineteene yeares agone at leaſt,
And yet the memory of it fits as freſh
Within my braine as twere but yeſterday)
It was that night wherein the great Chamont,
The generall for France ſurpriſed Vicenza,
Me thinks the horrour of that clamorous ſhout
His ſouldiers gaue 'when they attaind the wall,
Yet tingles in mine eare, me thinkes I ſee
With what amazed lookes, diſtracted thoughts,
And minds confuſ'd, we, that were citizens,
Confronted one another: euery ſtreet
Was fild with bitter ſelfe tormenting cries,
And happy was that foote, that firſt could preſſe,
The flowry champaigne, bordering on Verona
Heere I (imploy'd about my deare wiues ſafety)
Whoſe ſoule is now in peace) loſt my Camillo.
Who ſure was murdered by the barbarous Souldiers,
Or elſe I ſhould haue heard—my heart is great.

l.hi: Sorrow is faint? and paſſion makes me ſweat.

sp.speaker: Max
sp.p: Grieue not ſweet Count: comfort your ſpirts, you haue a ſonne a noble gentleman, he ſtands in the face of honour: For his ſafety let that be no queſtion. I am maiſter of my fortune, and he ſhall ſhare with me. Farewell my honorable Lord. Ladies once more adiew, for your ſelfe maddam you are a moſt rare creature, I tell you ſo, be not proud of it, I loue you: come Lord Paulo to horſe.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Adiew good Signior Franceſco: farewell ſiſter.

div.stage: Sound a tucket, and as they paſſe euery one ſeuerally depart, Maximilian, Paulo Ferneze and Angelo remaine

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How ſhall we rid him hence.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Why well inough? ſweet Signior Maximilian.
I haue ſome ſmall occaſion to ſtay:
If it may pleaſe you but take horſe afore
Ile ouer take you, ere your troopes be ranged.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Your motion hath taſt wel: Lord Ferneze I go

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Now if my loue faire Rachel, were ſo happy,
But to looke forth. See fortune doth me grace.
Before I can demaund? how now loue.
Where is your father?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Gone abroad my Lord:

sp.speaker: Pau:
sp.p: Thats well,

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I but I feare heele preſently returne,
Are you now going my moſt honored Lord?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I my ſweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Before God, ſhe is a ſweet wench.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Rachel I hope I ſhall not need to vrge,
The ſacred purity of our effects,
As if it hung in triall or ſuſpence:
Since in our hearts, and by our mutuall vowes,
It is confirmd and ſeald in ſight of heauen.
Nay doe not weepe, why ſtarte you? feare not, Loue.
Your father cannot be returned ſo ſoone,
I prithee doe not looke ſo heauily
Thou ſhalt want nothing

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: No is your preſence nothing,
I ſhall want that, and wanting that, want all
For that is all to me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Content thee ſweet
I haue Made choiſe here of a conſtant friend
This gentleman? one, whoſe zealous loue
I doe repoſe more, then on all the world,
Thy beauteous ſelfe excepted: and to him,
Haue I committed my deere care of thee,
As to my genius, or my other ſoule.
Rsceiue hi gentle loue and what deffects,
My abſence proues, his preſence ſhall ſupply.
The time is enuious of our longer ſtay.
Farewell deere Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach:
sp.l: Moſt deere Lord, adew,
Heauen and honour crowne your deeds, and you,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Faiah tell me Angelio how doſt thou like her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Troth well my Lord, but ſhall I ſpeake my mind.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I prithee doe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: She is deriud too meanely to be wife
To ſuch a noble perſon, in my iudgement.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Nay then thy iudgement is to meene, I ſe •
Didſt thou neare read in difference of good
Tis more to ſhine in vertue then in bloud.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come you are ſo ſententious my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Here comes her father. How doſt thou good Iaques?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: God ſaue thee Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What ſhould this meane? Rachel open the dore.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sbloud how the poore ſlaue lookes, as though
He had bene hauuted by the ſpirit Lar,
Or ſeene the ghoſt of ſome great Satrapas.
In an vnſauory ſheet.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I muſe he ſpake no, belike he was amazd
Comming ſo ſuddenly and vnprepard? Well lets go:

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.l: SO now inough my heart, beat now no more;
At leaſt for this afright, what a could ſweat,
Flow'd on my browes, and ouer all my boſome!
Had I not reaſon? to behold my dore
Beſet with vnthrifts, and my ſelfe abroad?
Why Iaques? was their nothing in the houſe
Worth a continuall eye, a vigelent thought,
Whoſe head ſhould neuer nod, nor eyes once wincke?
Looke on my coate; my thoughts; worne quite thred bare,
That time could neuer couer with a nappe,
And by it learne, neuer with nappes of ſleepe,
To ſmother your conceipts of that you keepe.
But yet, I maruell, why theſe gallant youths
Spokeine ſo faire, and I eſteemd a beggar?
The end of flattery, is gaine, or lechery:
If they ſeeke gaine of me, they thinke me rich,
But that they do not: for their other obiect:
Tis in my handſome daughter, if it be.
And by your leaue, her handſomneſſe may tell them
My beggery counterfeits, and, that her neatneſſe,
Flowes from ſome ſtore of wealth, that breakes my coffers,
With this ſame engine, loue to mine owne breed.
But this is anſwered: Beggers will keepe fine,

l.hi: Their daughters, being faire, though themſelues pine.

div.l: Well then, it is for her, I, t'is ſure for her,
And I make her ſo briske for ſome of them,
That I might liue alone once with my gold.
O t'is a ſweet companion! kind and true,
A man may truſt it when his father cheats him;
Brother, or friend, or wife, ô wondrous pelfe,
"That which makes all men falſe, is true it ſelfe.
But now this maid, is but ſuppos'd my daughter:
For I being Steward to a Lord of France,
Of great eſtate, and wealth, called Lord Chammount,
He gone into the warres, I ſtole his treaſure,
(But heare not, any thing) I ſtole his treaſure,
And this his daughter, being but two yeares old,
Becauſe it lou'd me ſo, that it would leaue
The nurſe her ſelfe, to come into mine armes,
And had I left it, it would ſure haue dyed.
Now herein I was kinde, and had a conſcience;
And ſince her Lady mother that did dye
In child-bed of her, loued me paſſing well,
It may be nature faſhiond this affection,
Both in the child and her: but hees ill bred,
That ranſackes tombes, and doth deface the dead.
I'le therefore ſay no more: ſuppoſe the reſt,
Here haue I chang'd my forme, my name and hers.
And liue obſurely, to enioy more ſafe
My deereſt treaſure. But I muſt abroad, Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: VVhat is your pleaſure ſir?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Rachel I muſt abroad.
Lock thy ſelfe in, but yet take out the key,
That whoſoeuer peepes in at the key-hole,
May yet imagine there is none at home.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: But harke thee Rachel: ſay a theefe ſhould come,
And miſſe the key, he would reſoule indeede
None were at home, and ſo breake in the rather:
Ope the doore Rachel, ſet it open daughter;
But ſit in it thy ſelfe: and talke alowd,
As if there were ſome more in houſe with thee:
Put out the fire, kill the chimnies hart,
That it may breath no more then a dead man,
The more we ſpare my child, the more we gaine.

sp.speaker: CHriſt.
sp.p: What ſayes my fellow Onion? come on.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: All of a houſe ſir, but no fellowes, you are my Lords Steward, but I pray you what thinke you of loue, ſir?

sp.speaker: Chriſt.
sp.p: Of loue Onion? Why it's a very honourable humor.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay if it be but worſhipfull I care not.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Go to, it's honorable, checke not at the conceit of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: But in truth ſir, you ſhall do well to think well of loue:
For it thinkes well of you, in me, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Gramercy fellow Onion: I do thinke well, thou art in loue, art thou?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Partly ſir, but I am aſham'd to ſay wholy.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Well, I will further it in thee to any honeſt woman, or maiden, the beſt I can.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.l: Why now you come neere him ſir, he doth vaile,
He doth remunerate, he doth chaw the cud in the kindneſſe
Of an honeſt imperfection to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Chriſ
sp.p: But who is it thou loueſt fellow Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Mary a poore mans daughter, but none of the honeſteſt, I hope.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Why, wouldſt thou not haue her honeſt?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O no, for then I am ſure ſhe would not haue me. T'is Rachel de Prie.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Why, ſhe hath the name of a very vertuous mayden.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: So ſhee is ſir, but the fellow talkes in quiddits, he.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou haue me do in the matter?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Do nothing ſir, I pray you, but ſpeake for me.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: In what maner?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: My fellow Iuniper can tell you ſir.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Why as thus ſir. Your worſhip may commend him for a fellow fit for conſanguinity, and that he ſhaketh with defire of procreation, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: That were not ſo good, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: No ſir, why ſo ſir? what if you ſhould ſay to her, correborate thy ſelfe ſweete ſoule, let me diſtinguiſh thy pappes with my fingers, diuine Mumps, prety Paſtorella? lookeſt thou ſo ſweet and bounteous? comfort my friend here.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Well I perceiue you wiſh, I ſhould ſay ſomething may do him grace, and further his deſires, and that be ſure I will.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I thanke you ſir, God ſaue your life, I pray God ſir.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Your worſhip is too good to liue long: youle contaminate me no ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Command thou wouldeſt ſay, no good Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Health and wealth ſir.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: This wench wil • ſolicite for my ſelfe,
Making my Lord and maiſter priuy to it;
And if he ſecond me with his conſent,
I will proceede, as hauing long ere this,
Though her a worthy choyce to make my wife.

sp.speaker: AVre.
sp.l: Roome for a caſe of matrons coloured blacke,
How motherly my mothers death hath made vs?
I would I had ſome girles now to bring vp;
O I could make a wench ſo vertuous,
She ſhould ſay grace to euery bit of meate,
And gape no wider then a wafers thickneſſe:
And ſhe ſhould make French curſies, ſo moſt low,
That euery touch ſhould turne her ouer backward.

sp.speaker: Phoeni.
sp.l: Siſter, theſe words become not your atrire,
Nor your eſtate: our vertuous mothers death
Should print more deepe effects of ſorrow in vs,
Then may be worne out in ſo little time.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Siſter, faith you take too much Tobacco,
It makes you blacke within, as y'are without.
What true-ſtich ſiſter? both your ſides alike?
Be of a ſleighter worke: for of my word,
You ſhall be ſold as deere or rather deerer?
Will you be bound to cuſtomes and to rites?
Shed profitable teares, weepe for aduantage;
Or elſe, do all things, as you are enclynd.
Hate when your ſtomacke ſerues (ſaith the Phyſitian)
Not at eleuen and ſixe. So if your humour
Be now affected with this heauineſſe.
Giue me the reines and ſpare not, as I do,
In this my pleaſurable appetite,
It is Praeciſianiſme to alter that
With auſtere iudgement, that is giuen by nature.
I wept you ſaw too, when my mother dyed:
For then I found it eaſier to do ſo,
And fitter with my moode, then not to weepe.
But now tis otherwiſe, another time
Perhaps I ſhall haue ſuch deepe thoughts of her,
That I ſhall weepe a freſh, ſome twelue month hence,
And I will weepe, if I be ſo diſpos'd,
And put on blacke, as grimly then, as now;
Let the minde go ſtill with the bodies ſtature,

l.hi: Iudgement is fit for Iudges, giue me nature.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: See Signior Angelo here are the Ladies,
Go you and comfort one, Ile to the other.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Therefore I come ſir, I'le to the eldeſt.
God ſaue you Ladies, theſe ſad moodes of yours,
That make you chooſe theſe ſolitary walkes,
Are hurtfull for your beauties.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: If we had them.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Come, that condition might be for your hearts,
When you proteſt faith, ſince we cannot ſee them.
But this ſame heart of beauty, your ſweet face
Is in mine eye ſtill.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: O you cut my heart with your ſharpe eye.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Nay Lady thats not ſo, your heart's to hard.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: My beauties hart?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: O no.
I meane that regent of affection, Maddam,
That tramples on al loue with ſuch contempt • n this faire breaſt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No more, your drift is ſauour'd,
I had rather ſeeme hard hearted

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Then hard fauour'd,
Is that your meaning, Lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Go too ſir.
Your wits are freſh I know, they need no ſpur,

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And therefore you wil ride them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Say I doe.
They will not tire I hope?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No not with you, hark you ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tis much pitty Maddam.
You ſhould haue any reaſon to retaine
This ſigne of griefe, much leſſe the thing diſignde.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Griefes are more fit for Ladies then their pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That is for ſuch as follow nought but pleaſures.
But you that temper them ſo wel with vertues,
Vſing your griefes ſo it would prooue them pleaſures.
And you would ſeeme in cauſe of griefes & pleaſures equally pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.l: Sir ſo I do now.
It is the exceſſe of either that I ſtriue
So much to ſhun in all my proou'd endeauours,
Although perhaps vnto a generall eye,
I may appeare moſt wedded to my griefes,
Yet doth my mind forſake no taſt of pleaſure,
I meane that happy pleaſure of the ſoule,
Deuine and ſacred contemplation
Of that eternall, and moſt glorious bliſſe.
Propoſed as the crowne vnto our ſoules.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will be ſilent, yet that I may ſerue
But as a Decade in the art of memory
To put you ſtil in mind of your owne vertues
When your too ſerious thoughts make you too ſad)
Accept me for your ſeruant honored Lady.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Thoſe cerimonies are too comon ſignior Francis,
For your vncommon grauitie, and iudgement,
And fits them onely, that are nought but cerimony.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Come, I will not ſue, ſtally to be your ſeruant,
But a new tearme, will you be my refuge?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Your refuge, why ſir.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: That I might fly to you, when all elſe faile me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And you be good at flying, be my Plouer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay take away the P.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Tut, then you cannot fly.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ile warrant you. Ile borrow Cupids wings.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Maſſe then I feare me youle do ſtrange things:
I pray you blame me not, if I ſuſpect you,
Your owne confeſſion ſimply doth detect you,
Nay and you be ſo great in Cupids bookes,
T'will make me Iealous. you can with your lookes
(I warrant you) enflame a womans heart,
And at your pleaſure take loues golden dart,
And wound the breſt of any vertous maide.
Would I were hence: good Faith I am affraid,
You can conſtraine one ere they be aware,
To run mad for your loue?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O this is rate.

sp.speaker: COunt.
sp.l: Cloſe with my daughters gentlemen? wel done,
Tis like your ſelues: nay luſty Angelo,
Let not my preſence make you bauke your ſport,
I will not breake a minute of diſcourſe
Twixt you and one of your faire Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: One of my miſtreſſes? why thinks your Lordſhip I haue ſo many

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Many? no Angelo.
I do not thinke th'aſt many, ſome fourteene
I here thou haſt, euen of our worthieſt dames,
Of any note, in Millaine:

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord fourteene: it is not ſo.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By'th the Maſſe that iſt, here are their names to ſhew
Fourteene, or fifteene t'one. Good Angelo.
You need not be aſhamd of any of them,
They are gallants all.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sbloud you are ſuch a Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Nay ſtay ſweet Angelo, I am diſpoſed
A little to be pleaſant paſt my couſtome,
He's gone? he's gone, I haue diſgraſt him ſhrewdly,
Daughters take heede of him, he's a wild youth,
Looke what he ſayes to you beleeue him not,
He will ſweare loue to euery one he ſees.
Franciſco, giue them councell, good Franciſco,
I dare truſt thee with both, but him with neither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip yet may truſt both them with him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Well goe your waies away; how now Chriſtopher,
What newes with you?

sp.speaker: Chriſt.
sp.p: I haue an humble ſuit to your good Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A ſuit Chriſtopher? what ſuit I prithee?

sp.speaker: Chriſt.
sp.l: I would craue pardon at your Lordſhips hands,
If it ſeeme vaine or ſimple in your ſight.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ile pardon all ſimplicity, Chriſtopher,
What is thy ſuit?

sp.speaker: Chriſt.
sp.l: Perhaps being now ſo old a batcheler,
I ſhall ſeeme halfe vnwiſe, to bend my ſelfe
In ſtrict affection to a poore yong maide.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What? is it touching loue Chriſtopher?
Art thou diſpoſt to marry, why tis well.

sp.speaker: Chriſto.
sp.l: I, but your Lordſhip may imagine now
That I being ſteward of your honours houſe.
If I be maried once, will more regard
The maintenance of my wife and of my charge,
Then the due diſcharge of my place and office.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, no, Chriſtopher, I know thee honeſt.

sp.speaker: Chriſto.
sp.p: Good faith my Lord, your honour may ſuſpect it▪ but—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then I ſhould wrong thee, thou haſt euer been
Honeſt and true, and will be ſtill I knowe.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: I but this marriage alters many men:
And you may feare, it will do me my Lord,
But ere it do ſo? I will vndergoe
Ten thouſand ſeuerall deaths.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I know it man.
Who wouldſt thou haue I prithee?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: If your good Lordſhip, graunt me your conſent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Rachel de prie? what the poore beggers daughter?
Shees a right handſome maide, how poore ſoeuer,
And thou haſt my conſent, with all my hart.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I humbly thanke your honour. Ile now aſke her father.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Do ſo Chriſtofero thou ſhalt do well.
Tis ſtrange (ſhe being ſo poore) he ſhould affect her,
But this is more ſtrange that my ſelfe ſhould loue her.
I ſpide her, lately, at her fathers doore,
And if I did not ſee in her ſweet face
Gentry and nobleneſſe, nere truſt me more:
But this perſwaſion, fancie wrought in me,
That fancie being created with her lookes,
For where loue is he thinke his baſeſt obiect
Gentle and noble: I am farre in loue,
And ſhall be forc'd to wrong my honeſt ſteward,
For I muſt ſue, and ſeeke her for my ſelfe;
How much my duetie to my late dead wife,
And my owne deere renowne ſo ere it ſwaies,
He to her father ſtraight. Loue hates delays.

div.head: Scaene 8.
div.stage: Enter Onion, Iuniper, Valentine, Sebaſtian, Balthaſar, Martino.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Come on Ifaith, lets to ſome exerciſe or other my hearts: Fetch the hilts fellow Iuniper, wilt thou play:

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: I cannot reſolue you? tis as I am fitted with the ingenuity, quantity, or quality of the cudgell.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: How doſt thou baſtinado the poore cudgell with tearmes?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O Ingle, I haue the phraſes man, and the Anagrams and the Epitaphs, fitting the miſtery of the noble ſcience.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ile be hangd & he were not misbegotten of ſome fencer.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Sirrah Valentine, you can reſolue me now, haue they their maiſters of defence in other countries as we haue here in Italy?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O Lord, I, eſpecially they in Vtopia, there they performe their prizes and chalenges, with as great cerimony as the Italian or any nation elſe.

sp.speaker: Balt
sp.p: Indeed? how is the manner of it (for gods loue) good Valeniine?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Ingle? I prithee make recourſe vnto vs, wee are thy friends and familiars: ſweet Ingle.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why thus ſir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: God a mercy good Valentine, nay go on.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Silentium bonus ſocius Onionus, good fellow Onion be not ſo ingenious, and turbulent: ſo fir? and how? how ſweete Ingle?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Marry, firſt they are brought to the publicke Theater:

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What? ha? they Theater there

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Theaters? I and plaies to: both tragidy and comedy & ſet foorth with as much ſtate as can be imagined?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: By Gods ſo; a man is nobody, till he has trauelled.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: And how are their plaies? as ours are? extemporall?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O no? all premeditated things, and ſome of them very good I faith, my maiſter vſed to viſite them often when he was there.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Why how are they in a place where any man may ſee them?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I, in the common Theaters, I tell you. But the ſport is at a new play to obſerue the ſway and variety of oppinion that paſſeth it. A man ſhall haue ſuch a confus'd mixture of iudgement, powr'd out in the throng there, as ridiculous, as laughter it ſelfe: one ſaies he likes not the writing, another likes not the plot, another not the playing. And ſometimes a fellow that comes not there paſt once in fiue yeare at a Parliament time or ſo, will be as deepe myr'd in cenſuring as the beſt, and ſweare by Gods foote he would neuer ſtirre his foote to ſee a hundred ſuch as that is.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I muſt trauell to ſee theſe things, I ſhall nere think well of my ſelfe elſe.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Fellow Onion, Ile beare thy charges and thou wilt but pilgrimize it along with me, to the land of Vtopia.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Why but me thinkes ſuch rookes as theſe ſhould be aſham'd to iudge.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not a whit? the rankeſt ſtinkard of them all, will take vpon him as peremptory, as if he had writ himſelfe in artibus magiſter.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: And do they ſtand to a popular cenſure for any thing they preſent.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I euer, euer, and the people generally are very acceptiue and apt to applaud any meritable worke, but there are two ſorts of perſons that moſt commonly are infectious to a whole auditory.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: What be they?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: I come lets know them.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: It were good they were noted.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p:
Marry? one is the rude barbarous crue, a people that haue no braines, and yet grounded iudgements, theſe will hiſſe
any thing that mounts aboue their grounded capacities. But the other are worth the obſeruation, I faith.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What be they? what be they?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith a few Caprichious gallants.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Caprichious? ſtay, that word's for me.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: And they haue taken ſuch a habit of diſlike in all things, that they will approue nothing, be it neuer ſo conceited or elaborate, but ſit diſperſt, making faces, and ſpitting, wagging their vpright eares and cry filthy, filthy. Simply vttering their owne condition, and vſing their wryed countenances in ſtead of a vice, to turne the good aſpects of all that ſhall ſit neere them, from what they behold.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: O that's well ſayd, lay them downe, come ſirs.
Who plaies, fellow Iuniper, Sebaſtian, Balthaſar:
Some body take them vp, come.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not I ſir, I profeſſe it not.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Who? I?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Come, but one bout, Ile giue hem thee, I faith.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Why, heres Martino.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Foe he, alas he cannot play a whit, man.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: That's all one: no more could you in ſtata quo prius, Martino, play with him, euery man has his beginning and conduction.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Will you not hurt me fellow Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Hurt thee, no? and I do, put me among pot-hearbs, And chop me to peeces, come on?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: By your fauor ſweet bullies giue them roome, back, ſo, Martino, do not looke ſo thin vpon the matter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ha, well plaid, fall ouer to my legge now? ſo, to your guard againe, excellent, to my head now, make home your blow: ſpare not me, make it home, good, good a gaine.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Why how now Peter?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Gods ſo, Onion has caught a bruiſe.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Couragio? be not caprichious? what?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Caprichious? not I, I ſcorn to be caprichious for a ſcrach, Martino muſt haue another bout, come.

sp.speaker: Val. Seb. Balth.
sp.p: No, no, play no more, play no more.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Foe, tis nothing a philip, a deuiſe, fellow Iuniper prithee get me a Plantan, I had rather play with one that had skil by halfe.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: By my troth, fellow Onion, twas againſt my will.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: Nay that's not ſo, twas againſt my head,
But come, weele ha one bout more.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Not a bout, not a ſtroke.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No more, no more.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Why Ile giue you demonſtration, how it came, Thou openeſt the dagger to falſifie ouer with the back ſword frick, and he interrupted, before he could fall to the cloſe.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No, no, I know beſt how it was better thē any man here, I felt his play preſently: for looke you, I gathered vpon him thus, thus do you ſee? for the double locke, and tooke it ſingle on the head.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: He ſayes very true, he tooke it ſingle on the head.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Come lets go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here fellow Onion, heres a cob-web.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: How? a cob-web Martino, I will haue another bout with you? S'wounds do you firſt breake my head, and then giue me a plaiſter in ſcorne? come to it, I will haue a bout.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: God's my witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Tut! your witneſſe cannot ſerue.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: S'bloud? why what, thou art not lunatike, art thou? and thou bee'ſt auoide Mephoſtophiles. Say the ſigne ſhoud be in Aries now: as it may be for all vs, where were your life? Anſwere me that?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: Hee ſayes well, Onion.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I indeed doo's he.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p:
Come, come, you are a fooliſh Naturaliſt, go, get a white a of an egge, and a little flax, and cloſe the breach of the
head, it is the moſt conducible thing that can be. Martino, do not inſinuate vpon your good fortune, but play an honeſt part and beare away the bucklers.

sp.speaker: ANge.
sp.l: My yong and ſimple friend, Paulo Ferneze,
Bound me with mighty ſolemne coniurations,
To be true to him, in his loue, to Rachel,
And to ſolicite his remembrance ſtill,
In his enforced abſence, much, I faith.
True to my friend in caſes of affection?
In womens caſes? what a ieſt it is?
How ſilly he is, that imagines it!
He is an aſſe that will keepe promiſe ſtricktly
In any thing that checkes his priuate pleaſure;
Chiefly in loue. S'bloud am not I a man?
Haue I not eyes that are as free to looke?
And bloud to be enflam'd as well as his?
And when it is ſo, ſhall I not purſue
Mine owne loues longings, but preferre my friends?
I tis a good foole, do ſo, hang me then,
Becauſe I ſwore, alas, who doo's not know,
That louers periuries are ridiculous?
Haue at thee Rachel: Ile go court her ſure:
For now I know her father is abroad.
S'bloud ſee, he is here, ô what damn'd lucke is this?
This labour's loſt, I muſt by no meanes ſee him.

sp.speaker: IAq.
sp.l: Miſchiefe and hell, what is this man a ſpirit,
Haunts he my houſes ghoſt? ſtill at my doore?
He has beene at my doore, he has beene in,
In my deere doore: pray God my gold be ſafe.
Gods pitty, heres another. Rachel, ho Rachel.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: God ſaue you honeſt father.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Rachel, Gods light, come to me, Rachel, Rachel!

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: Now in Gods name what ayles he? this is ſtrange!
He loues his daughter ſo, Ile lay my life,
That hee's afraid, hauing beene now abroad,
I come to ſeeke her loue vnlawfully.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Tis ſafe, tis ſafe, they haue notrob'd my treaſure.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Let it not feeme offenſiue to you ſir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Sir, Gods my life, ſir, ſir, call me ſir.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Good father here me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: You are moſt welcome ſir,
I meant almoſt; and would your worſhip ſpeake?
Would you abaſe your ſelfe to ſpeake to me?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: Tis no abaſing father: my intent
Is to do further honour to you ſir
Then onely ſpeake: which is to be your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My gold is in his noſtrels, he has ſmelt it,
Breake breaſt, breake heart, fall on the earth my entrailes,
With this ſame burſting admiration!
He knowes my gold, he knowes of all my treaſure,
How do you know ſir? whereby do you gueſſe?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: At what ſir? what iſt you meane?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I aske, an't pleaſe your Gentle worſhip, how you know?
I meane, how I ſhould make your worſhip know
That I haue nothing —
To giue with my poore daughter? I haue nothing:
The very aire, bounteous to euery man,
Is ſcant to me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I do thinke good father, you are but poore,

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: He thinkes ſo, harke, but thinke ſo:
He thinkes not ſo, he knowes of all my treaſure.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: Poore man he is ſo ouerioyed to heare
His daughter may be paſt his hopes beſtowed,
That betwixt feare and hope (if I meane ſimply)
He is thus paſſionate.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Yet all is ſafe within, is none without?
No body breake my walles?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: What ſay you father, ſhall I haue your daughter?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I haue no dowry to beſtow vpon her.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I do expect none, father.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: That is well,
Then I beſeech your worſhip make no queſtion
Of that you wiſh, tis too much fauour to me.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: Ile leaue him now to giue his paſſions breath,
Which being ſetled, I will fetch his daughter:
I ſhall but moue too much, to ſpeake now to him.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: So, hee's gone, would all were dead and gone,
That I might liue with my deere gold alone.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Here is the poore old man.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Out of my ſoule another, comes he hither?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Be not diſmaid old man, I come to cheere you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: To me by heauen,
Turne ribs to braſſe, turne voice into a trumpet,
To rattle out the battels of my thoughts,
One comes to hold me talke, while th'other robbes me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He has forgot me ſure: what ſhould this meane?
He feares authority, and my want of wife
Will take his daughter from him to defame her:
He that hath naught on earth but one poore daughter,
May take this extaſie of care to keepe her.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: And yet tis ſafe: they meane not to vſe force,
But fawning comming. I ſhall eaſly know
By his next queſtion, if he thinke me rich,
Whom ſee I? my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Stand vp good father, I call thee not father for thy age,
But that I gladly wiſh to be thy ſonne,
In honoured marriage with thy beauteous daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O, ſo, ſo, ſo, ſo, ſo, this is for gold,
Now it is ſure, this is my daughters neatneſſe,
Makes them beleeue me rich. No, my good Lord,
Ile tell you all; how my poore hapleſſe daughter
Got that attire ſhe weares from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why father, this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O yes, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed it is not.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Nay ſweet Lord pardon me? do not diſſemble,
Heare your poore beadſ-man ſpeake; tis requiſite
That I (ſo huge a beggar) make account
Of things that paſſe my calling: ſhe was borne
T'enioy nothing vnderneath the ſonne:
But that, if ſhe had more then other beggars
She ſhould be enuied: I will tell you then
How ſhe had all ſhe weares, her warme ſhooes (God wot)
A kind maide gaue her, ſeeing her go barefoot
In a cold froſty morning; God requite her;
Her homely ſtockings

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Father, Ile heare no more, thou mou'ſt too much
With thy too curious anſwere for thy daughter,
That doth deſerue a thouſand times as much,
Ile be thy Sonne in law, and ſhe ſhall weare
Th'attire of Counteſſes.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O good my Lord,
Mock not the poore, remembers not your Lordſhip,
That pouerty is the precious gift of God.
As well as riches, tread vpon me, rather
Then mocke my poorenes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Riſe I ſay:
When I mocke poorenes, then heauens make me poore.

sp.speaker: NVn.
sp.l: See heres the Count Ferneze, I will tell him
The hapleſſe accident of his braue ſonne,
That hee may ſeeke the ſooner to redeeme him,
God ſaue your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You are right welcome ſir.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: I would I brought ſuch newes as might deſerue it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, bring you me ill newes?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Tis ill my Lord,
Yet ſuch as vſuall chance of warre affoords,
And for which all men are prepar'd that vſe it,
And thoſe that vſe it not, but in their friends,
Or in their children.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ill newes of my ſonne?
My deere and onely ſonne, Ile lay my ſoule,
Ay me accurs'd, thought of his death doth wound me,
And the report of it will kill me quite.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Tis not ſo ill my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Hee's taken priſoner, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That's enough, enough,
I ſet my thoughts on loue, on ſeruile loue,
Forget my vertuous wife, feele not the dangers,
The bands and wounds of mine owne fleſh and bloud,
And therein am a mad man: therein plagu'd,
With the moſt iuſt affliction vnder heauen.
Is Maximilian taken priſoner to?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: My good my Lord, he is return'd with priſoners.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Iſt poſſible, can Maximilian?
Returne, and view my face without my ſonne,
For whom he ſwore ſuch care as for himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: My Lord no care can change the euents of war.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O! in what tempeſts do my fortunes ſaile,
Still wrackt with winds more foule and contrary,
Then any northen gueſt, or Southerne flawe?
That euer yet inforc't the ſea to gape,
And ſwallow the poore Marchants traffique vp?
Firſt in Vieenza, loſt I my firſt ſonne;
Next here in Millaine my moſt deere lou'd Lady:
And now my Paulo, priſoner to the French,
Which laſt being printed with my other griefes,
Doth make ſo huge a volume, that my breſt
Cannot containe them. But this is my loue▪
I muſt make loue to Rachel, heauen hath throwne,
This vengeance on me moſt deſeruedly:
Were it for nought but wronging of my ſteward.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: My Lord ſince onely mony may redreſſe
The worſt of this miſfortune, be not griued,
Prepare his ranſome and your noble ſonne
Shall greete your cheered eyes, with the more honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I will prepare his ranſome: gratious heauen
Grant his impriſonment may be his worſt,
Honored and ſouldier-like impriſonment,
And that he be not manacled and made
A drudge to his proude foe. And here I vow,
Neuer to dreame of ſeeme-les amorous toyes,
Nor aime at other ioy on earth,
But the fruition of my onely ſonne.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Iaques with his gold and aſcuttle full of horſe-dung.

sp.speaker: Iaq,
sp.l: He's gone: I knew it; this is our hot louer,
I will beleeue them! I! they may come in
Like ſimple woers, and be arrant theeues,
And I not know them! tis not to be told,
What ſeruile villanies, men will do for gold,
O it began to haue a huge ſtrong ſmell,
Which lying ſo long together in a place;
Ile giue it vent, it ſhall ha ſhift inough,
And if the diuell, that enuies all goodneſſe,
Haue told them of my gold, and where I kept it,
Ile ſet his burning noſe once more a worke,
To ſmell where I remou'd it, here it is:
Ile hide and couer it with this horſe-dung:
Who will ſuppoſe that ſuch a precious ne • t
Is crownd with ſuch a dunghill excrement?
In my deere life, ſleepe ſweetly my deere child.
"Scarce lawfully begotten, but yet gotten,
"And thats enough. Rot all hands that come neere thee
Except mine owne. Burne out all eyes that ſee thee,
Except mine owne. All thoughts of thee be poyſon
To their enamor'd harts, except mine owne,
Ile take no leaue, ſweet Prince great Emperour,
But ſee thee euery minute, King of Kings,
Ile not be rude to thee, and turne my backe,
In going from thee, but go backward out:
With my face toward thee, with humble curteſies,
None is within. None ouerlookes my wall.
To haue gold, and to haue it ſafe, is all.

div.head: Scaene 1.
div.stage: Enter Maximilian, with ſouldiers Chamount, Camilla, Ferneze, Pacue.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Lord Chamount and your valient friend there, I cannot ſay welcome to Millaine: your thoughts and that word are not muſicall, but I can ſay you are come to Millaine.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mort diew.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Gar ſoone.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Gentlemen (I would cal an Emperour ſo) you are now my priſoners, I am ſorry, marry this, ſpit in the face of your fortunes, for your vſage ſhall be honorable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Wee know it ſignior Maximilian,
The fame of al your actions ſounds nought elſe,
But perfect honour from her ſwelling cheeks.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: It ſhall do ſo ſtill I aſſure you, and I will giue you reaſon, there is in this laſt action (you know) a noble gentleman of our party, & a right valient; ſemblably priſoner to your general, as your honor'd ſelfe's to me, for whoſe ſafety, this tongue hath giuen warrant to his honorable father, the Count Ferneze. You conceiue me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I ſignior.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Well? then I muſt tell you your ranſomes be to redeeme him, what thinke you? your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Marry with my Lords leaue here I ſay ſignior,
This free & ample offer you haue made,
Agrees well with your honour, but not ours:
For I thinke not but Chamount is aſwell borne
As is Ferneze, then if I miſtake not,
He ſcornes to haue his worth ſo vnderpriſed,
That it ſhould neede an adiunct, in exchange,
Of any equall fortune, Noble Signior?
I am a ſouldier, and I loue Chamount,
Ere I would bruſe his eſtimation,
With the leaſt ruine of mine owne reſpect,
In this vild kind, theſe legs ſhould rot with irons,
This body pine in priſon, till the fleſh
Dropt from my bones in flakes, like withered leaues,
In heart of Autumne, from a ſtubborne Oke.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Mounſieur Gaſper (I take it ſo is your name) miſpriſe me not, I wil trample on the hart, on the ſoule of him that ſhall ſay, I will wrong you: what I purpoſe, you cannot now know; but you ſhall know, and doubt not to your contentment. Lord Chamount, I will leaue you, whileſt I go in and preſent my ſelfe to the honorable Count, till my regreſſion ſo pleaſe you, your noble feete may meaſure this priuate, pleaſant and moſt princely walke, Souldiers regard them and reſpect them.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p:
O Ver bon: excellenta gull, he tak'a my Lord Chamoun •
for Mounſieur Gaſpra, & Mounſieur Gaſpra for my Lord Chamont, ô dis be braue for make a me laugh'a, ha, ha, ha, ô my heart tickla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I but your Lordſhip knowes not what hard fate
Might haue purſued vs, therefore howſoere
The changing of our names was neceſſary
And we muſt now be carefull to maintaine
This error ſtrongly, which our owne deuiſe,
Hath thruſt into their ignorant conceits,
For ſhould we (on the taſte of this good fortune)
Appeare our ſelues, t'would both create in them
A kinde of iealouſie, and perchaunce inuert
Thoſe honourable courſes they intend.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: True my deere Gaſper: but this hang by here,
Will (at one time or other) on my ſoule
Diſcouer vs: A ſecret in his mouth
Is like a wild bird put into a cage,
Whoſe doore no ſooner opens, but tis out.
But ſirra, if I may but know
Thou vtterſt it

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Vtteria? vat Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That he is Gaſper, and I true Chamont.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O pardone moy, fore my tongue ſhall put out de ſecreta,
Shall breede de cankra in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Speake not ſo loud Pacue.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Foe, you ſhall not heare foole, for all your long eare, Reguard Mounſieur: you be de Chamont, Chamont be Gaſpra.

div.stage: Enter Count Ferueze, Maximilian, Franceſco, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Finio.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Peace, here comes Maximilian.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: O belike that's the Count Ferneze, that old man.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Are thoſe his daughters, trow?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I ſure, I thinke they are.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Fore God the taller is a gallant Lady.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So are they both beleeue me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: True my honorable Lord, that Chamont was the father of this man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O that may be, for when I loſt my ſonne,
This was but yong it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Faith had Camillo liued,
He had beene much about his yeares, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He had indeed, well, ſpeake no more of him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Signior perceiue you the errour? twas no good office in vs to ſtretch the remembrance of ſo deere a loſſe. Count Ferneze, let ſommer ſit in your eye, looke cheerefully ſweete Count, will you do me the honour to confine this noble ſpirit within the circle of your armes?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Honor'd Chamont reach me your valiant hand,
I could haue wiſht ſome happier accident
Had made the way vnto this mutuall knowledge,
Which either of vs now muſt take of other,
But ſure it is the pleaſure of our fates,
That we ſhould thus be wrack't on Fortunes wheele,
Let vs prepare with ſteeled patience
To tread on torment, and with mindes confirm'd
Welcome the worſt of enuy.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Noble Lord, tis thus. I haue here (in mine honour) ſet this gentleman free, without ranſome, he is now himſelfe, his valour hath deſeru'd it, in the eye of my iudgement. Mounſieur Gaſper you are deere to me: fortuna non mutuat genus. But to the maine, if it may ſquare with your Lordſhips liking, and his loue, I could deſire that he were now inſtantly imployed to your noble Generall in the exchange of Ferneze for your ſelfe, it is the buſineſſe that requires the tender hand of a friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I, and it would be with more ſpeed effected,
If he would vndertake it.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: True my Lord. Mounſieur Gaſper, how ſtand you affected to this motion?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My duty muſt attend his Lordſhips will.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: What ſayes the Lord Chamont?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My will doth then apprroue what theſe haue vrg'd.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Why there is good harmony, good muſicke in thise Mounſieur Gaſper, you ſhall protract no time, onely I will giue you a bowle of rich wine to the health of your Generall, another to the ſucceſſe of your iourney, and a third to the loue of my ſword. Paſſe.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Aurelia and Phoenixella.

sp.speaker: Anre.
sp.l: Why how now ſiſter in a motley muſe?
Go to, thers ſomewhat in the wind, I ſee.
Faith this browne ſtudy ſuites not with your blacke,
Your habit and your thoughts are of two colours.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Good faith me thinkes that this young Lord Chamont fauours my mother, ſiſter, does he not?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: A mothelry conceite, ô blind excuſe,
Blinder then loue himſelfe. Well ſiſter, well.
Cupid hath tane his ſtand in both your eyes, The caſe is alterd.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Nay nothing but a Saint.
Another Bridget, one that for a face
Would put downe Veſta, in whoſe lookes doth ſwim,
The very ſweeteſt creame of modeſty.
You to turne tippet? fie, fie, will you giue
A packing penny to Virginity.
I thought youl'd dwell ſo long in Cypres Ile,
You'd worſhip Maddam Venus at the length;
But come, the ſtrongeſt fall, and why not you?
Nay, do not frowne.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Go. go, you ſoole. Adiew.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Well I may ieſt, or ſo: but Cupid knowes
My taking is as bad, or worſe then hers.
O Mounſieur Gaſper? if thou bee'ſt a man,
Be not affraid to court me, do but ſpeake,
Challenge thy right and weare it: for I ſweare
Till thou arriud'ſt, nere came affection here.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.l: Come on my ſweet finicall Pacue, the very prime
Of Pages, heres an excellent place for vs to practiſe in,
No body fees vs here, come lets to it.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Contenta: Reguarde, vou le Preimer.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Sirra Finio?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mort deiu le peſant.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Didſt thou ſee Valentine?

sp.speaker: Finio.
sp.p: Valentine? no.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Fini.
sp.p: No. Sirrah Onion, whither goeſt?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O I am vext, he that would truſt any of theſe lying trauellers.

sp.speaker: Finio.
sp.p: I prithee ſtay good Onion.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mounſieur Onion, vene ca, come hidera, Ie vou prey. By gar me ha ſee two, tree, foure hundra towſand of your Couſan hang. Lend me your hand, ſhall prey for know you bettra.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I thanke you good ſignior Parla vou? O that I were in an other world, in the Ingies, or ſome where, that I might haue roome to laugh.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: A we fort boon: ſtand? you be deere now, me come, Boon iour Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: God morrow good ſignior.

sp.speaker: Pac
sp.p: By gar, be muſh glad for ſee you.

sp.speaker: Fin
sp.p: I returne you moſt kind thanks ſir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: How? how? Sbloud this is rare?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay, ſhall make you ſay rare by and by, Reguard Mounſieur Finio,

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Signior Pache.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Dieu vou gard Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: God ſaue you ſweet ſignior

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mounſieur On ion? is not fort boon.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Beane? quoth he, would I were in debt of a pottle of beanes I could do as much.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Welcome ſignior, whats next?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O here, Void de grand admiration, as ſhould meet perchance Mounſieur Finio,

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Mounſieur Pacue

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Ieſu? by Gar who thinke wee ſhall meete here?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: By this hand I am not a little proud of it, ſir

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: This trick is onely for the the chamber, it cannot be cleanly done abroad,

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Well what ſay you for dis den? Mounſieur:

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Nay pray, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Par ma foy vou bein encounters?

sp.speaker: Fin
sp.p: What doe you meane ſir, let your gloue alone.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Comen, ſe porte la ſante.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Faith exceeding well ſir.

sp.speaker: Pac,
sp.p: Trot, be muſh ioy for heire.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And how iſt with you ſweet ſignior Pache.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Fat comme vou voyer.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Yong gentlemen? ſpirits of bloud, if euer youle taſt of a ſweet peece of mutton, do Onion a good turne now.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Que que, parla Mounſeir, what iſt.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Faith teach me one of theſe tricks.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O me ſhall doe preſently, ſtand you deere, you ſignior deere, my ſelfe is here: ſo fort bein, now I parle to Mounſeir Onion, Onion pratla to you, you ſpeaka to me, ſo, and as you parle chang the bonet, Mounſeir Onion.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Mounſeiur Finio.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Mounſeur Pacue.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pray be couera.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: What do you meane.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pardon moy, ſhall be ſo,

sp.speaker: Oni
sp.p: O God ſir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Not I in good faith ſir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: By gar you muſt.

sp.speaker: Oni:
sp.p: It ſhall be yours.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Nay then you wrong me,

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well and euer I come to be great.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: You be big enough for de Onion already,

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I meane a great man.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Then thou'dſt be a monſter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well God knowes not what fortune may doe, commaund me, vſe me from the ſoule to the crowne, and the crowne to the ſoule: meaning not onely from the crowne of the head, and the ſole of the foot, but alſo the foote of the mind and the crownes of the purſe, I cannot ſtay now yong gentlemen but — time was, time is, and time ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Sweet Iaſper I am ſorry we muſt part,
But ſtrong neceſſity enforceth it.
Let not the time ſeeme long vnto my friend,
Till my returne for by our loue I ſweare
(The ſacred ſpheare wherein our ſoules are knit)
I will endeauour to effect this buſines
With all induſtrious care and happy ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord theſe circumſtances would come well,
To one leſſe capable of your deſert
Then I: in whom your mirrit is confirmed
With ſuch authenticall and grounded proues.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well I will vſe no more. Gaſper adiew.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Farewell my honored Lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Commend me to the Lady, my good Gaſper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I had remembred that had not you vrgd it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Once more adiew ſweet Gaſper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thy vertues are more precious then thy name,
Kind gentleman I would not ſell thy loue,
For all the earthly obiects that mine eyes,
Haue euer taſted, ſure thou art nobly borne,
How euer fortune hath obſcurd thy birth:
For natiue honour ſparkles in thine eyes,
How may I bleſſe the time wherein Chamont
My honored father did ſurpriſe vicenza,
Where this my friend (knowen by no name) was found,
Being then a child and ſcarce of power to ſpeake,
To whom my father gaue this name of Gaſper,
