And as his owne reſpected him to death,
Since when wee two haue ſhard our mutuall fortunes,
With equall ſpirits, and but deathes rude hand,
No violence ſhall diſſolue this ſacred band.

div.stage: Enter Iuniper in his ſhop ſinging: to him Onion.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Fellow Iuniper, no more of thy ſongs and ſonets, ſweet Iuniper, no more of thy hymnes and madrigals, thou ſing'ſt, but I ſigh.

sp.speaker: Iuni
sp.p: Whats the matter Peter ha? what in an Academy ſtill, ſtill in ſable, and coſtly black array? ha?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Prithee riſe mount, mount ſweet Iuniper, for I goe downe the wind, and yet I puffe: for I am vext.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p:
Ha Bully? vext? what intoxicate? is thy braine in a
quinteſcence? an Idea? a metamorphoſis? an Apology? ha rogue? come this loue feeds vpon thee, I ſee by thy cheekes, and drinkes healthes of vermilion, teares I ſee by thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I confeſſe Cupids carouſe, he plaies ſuper negulum with my liquor of life

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tut, thou art a gooſe to be Cupids gull, go to, no more of this contemplations, & calculations, mourne not, for Rachels thine owne

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: For that let the higher powers worke: but ſweet Iuniper, I am not ſad for her, and yet for her in a ſecond perſon, or • f not ſo yet in a third.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: How ſecond perſon? away, away, in the crotchets already Longitude and Latitude? what ſecond? what perſon? ha?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Iuniper, Ile bewray my ſelfe before thee, for thy company is ſweet vnto me, but I muſt entreat thy helping hand in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tut? no more of this ſurquedry; I am thine owne? ad vngem vpſie freeze: pell mell, come, what caſe? what caſe?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p:
For the caſe it may be any mans caſe, aſwell as mine, Rachel I meane, but Ile medle with her anon, in the meane time,
•• lentine is the man hath wrongd me.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: How my Ingle wrong thee, iſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Your Ingle, hang him infidell, well and if I be not reuengd one him let Peter Onion (by the infernall Gods) be turned to al eeke or a ſcalion, I ſpake to him for a ditty for this handkerchier.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Why, has he not done it?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Done it, not a verſe by this hand.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O in dichus illis, O prepoſterous, wel come be blith, the • eſt iud ••… of the • l is ſomtimes dul, fellow Onion pardon mine Iugle: he is a man, has in pefections and declinations, as other men haue, his maſſe ſomtimes cannot carnet nor progniſticat and come of, as it ſhould, no matter, Ile hammer our a paral •… raſe for thee my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p:
No ſweet Iuniper, no danger 〈◊〉 breed delay, loue
makes me chollericke I can beare no longer.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Not beare? what my mad Meridian ſlaue? not be are? what?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Cupids burden: tis to heauy, to tollerable, and as for the handkerchire and the poſie: I will not trouble thee: but if thou wilt goe with me into her fathers backſide, old Iaques backſide, and ſpeake for me to Rachel, I wil not being ratitude, the old man is abroad and all.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Art thou ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: As ſure as an obligation.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Lets away then, come we ſpend time in a vaine circumference, trade •… caſhire thee til to morrow, fellow Onion for thy ſake I fini •• this workiday.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: God a mercy, and for thy ſake Ile at any time make a holiday.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay I prithee Rachel, I come to comfort thee, Be not ſo ſad.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O ſignior Angelo,
No comfort but his preſence can remoue,
This ſadneſſe from my heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay then y'are fond,
And want that ſtrength of iudgement and election,
That ſhould be attendent on your yeares and forme,
Will you, becauſe your Lord is taken priſoner,
Blubber and weepe and keepe a peeuiſh ſtirre,
As though you would turne turtle with the newes,
Come, come, be wiſe. Sblood ſay your Lord ſhould die:
And you goe marre your face as you begin,
What would you doe trow? who would care for you;
But this it is, when nature will beſtow
Her gifts on ſuch as know not how to vſe them,
You ſhall haue ſome that had they but one quarter
Of your faire beauty? they would make it ſhew
A little otherwiſe then you do this,
Or they would ſee the painter twice an hower,
And I commend them I, that can vſe art,
With ſuch iudiciall practiſe.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: You talke iedly,
If this be your beſt comfort keepe it ſtill,
My ſences cannot feede on ſuch ſower cates.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And why ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Nay leaue good ſignior.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come I haue ſweeter vyands yet in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: I in any caſe miſtres Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Gods pitty ſignior Angelo, I here my father, away for Gods ſake.

sp.speaker: Ang:
sp.p: S'bloud, I am betwixt, I thinke, this is twice now, I haue been ſerued thus.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Pray God he meet him not.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O braue? ſhe's yonder, O terrible ſhee's gone.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Yea? ſo nimble in your Dilemma's, and your Hiperbole's Hay my loue? O my loue, at the firſt ſight: By the maſſe.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O how ſhe ſkudded, O ſweet ſcud, how ſhe tripped, O delicate trip and goe.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Come thou art enamored with the influence of her profundity, but ſirrah harke a little.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O rare, what? what? paſſing Ifaith, what iſt? what iſt?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What wilt thou ſay now, if Rachel ſtand now, and play hity tity through the key hole, to behold the equipage of thy perſon:

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O ſweet equipage, try good Iuniper, tickle her, talke, talke, O? rare

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Miſtris Rachel (watch then if her father come) Rachel? Madona? Rachel? No.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Say I am here, Onion or Peter or ſo.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: No, Ile knock, weele not ſtand vpon Horizons, and tricks, but fall roundly to the matter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well ſaid ſweet Iuniper: Horizons? hang hem? knock, knock.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Whoſe there? father.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Father no? and yet a father, if you pleaſe to be a mother.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well ſaid Iuniper, to her againe, a ſmack or two more of the mother

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Do you here? ſweet ſoule, ſweet radamant? ſweet mathauell one word Melpomine? are you at leaſure.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: At leaſure? what to doe?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: To doe what, to doe nothing, but to be liable to the extaſie of true loues exigent, or ſo, you ſmell my meaning.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Smell, filthy, fellow Iuniper filthy? ſmell? O moſt odious.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: How filthy.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Filthy, by this finger? ſmell? ſmell a rat, ſmel a pudding, away theſe tricks are for truls, a plaine wench loues plaine dealing, ile vpon my ſelfe, ſmel to march paine wench.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: With all my heart, Ile be legitimate and ſilent as anapple-ſquire, Ile ſee nothing, and ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Sweet hart, ſweet hart?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: And bag pudding, ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What Rachel my girle what Rachel;

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Gods lid▪

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What Rachel,

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Here I am

sp.speaker: Oni
sp.p: What rakehell cals Rachel: O treaſon to my loue.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Its her father on my life, how ſhall wee entrench and edifie our ſelues from him?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O conni-catching▪ Cupid.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: How in my back ſide? where? what come they for?
sp.stage: Onion gets vp into a tree.
sp.l: Where are they? Rachel? theeues, theeues?
Stay villaine ſlaue: Rachel? vntye my dog.
Nay theife thou canſt not ſcape.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: I pray you ſir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: A pitifull Onion, that thou hadſt a rope.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Why Rachel: when I ſay: let looſe my dog? garlique my maſtiue, let him looſe I ſay.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: For Gods ſake here me ſpeake, keepe vp your cur.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I feare not garlique, heele not bite Onion his kinſman pray God he come out, and then theile not ſmell me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: well then deliuer, come deliuer ſlaue?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What ſhould I deliuer?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O thou wouldſt haue me tell thee? wouldſt thou ſhew me thy hands, what haſt thou in thy hands?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Here be my hands.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Stay are not thy fingers ends begrimd with durt, no thou haſt wipt them.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Wipt them?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I thou villaine? thou art a ſubtile knaue, put off thy ſhewes, come I will ſee them, giue me a knife here Rachel, Ile rip the ſoles.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No matter he's a cobler, he can mend them.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What are you mad? are you deteſtable, would you make an Anatomy of me, thinke you I am not true Ortographie?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ortographie, Anatomy?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: For Gods ſake be not ſo inuiolable, I am no ambuſcado, what predicament call you this, why do you intimate ſo much.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I can feele nothing.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Bir Lady but Onion feeles ſomething.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Soft ſir, you are not yet gon, ſhake your legs, come, and your armes, be briefe, ſtay let me ſee theſe drums, theſe kilderkins, theſe bombard ſlops, what is it crams hem ſo.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Nothing but haire.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Thats true, I had almoſt forgot this rug, this hedghogs neſt, this hay mowe, this beares ſkin, this heath, this firſbuſh.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p:
O let me goe, you teare my haire, you reluolue my
braines and vnderſtanding.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Heart, thou art ſomewhat eas'd? halfe of my feare
Hath tane his leaue of my, the other halfe
Still keepes poſſeſſion in diſpight of hope,
Vntill theſe amorous eyes, court my faire gold:
Deare I come to thee: friend, why art not gone?
Auoid my ſoules vexation, Sathan hence?
Why doeſt thou ſtare on me, why doeſt thou ſtay?
Why por'ſt thou on the ground with theeuiſh eyes?
What ſee'ſt thou there, thou curre? what gap'ſt thou at?
Hence from my houſe, Rachel, ſend garlick forth.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: I am gone ſir, I am gone, for Gods ſake ſtay.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Pack, and thanke God thou ſcap'ſt ſo well away.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: If I ſcape this tree, deſtinies, I defie you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I cannot ſee by any Characters
Writ on this earth, that any fellon foote
Hath tane acquaintance of this hallowed ground.
None ſees me: knees do homage to your Lord.
Tis ſafe, tis ſafe, it lyes and ſleepes ſo ſoundly,
Twould do one good to looke on't. If this bliſſe
Be giuen to any man that hath much gold,
Iuſtly to ſay tis ſafe, I ſay tis ſafe.
O what a heauenly round theſe two words dance
Within me and without me: Firſt I thinke hem,
And then I ſpeake hem, then I watch their ſound,
And drinke it greedily with both mine eares,
Then thinke, then ſpeake, then drinke their ſound againe,
And racket round about this bodies court.
Theſe two ſweet words: tis ſafe: ſtay I will feed
My other ſences, ô how ſweet it ſmels

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I mar'le he ſmels not Onion, being ſo neere it.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Downe to thy graue againe, thou beauteous Ghoſt,
Angels men ſay, are ſpirits: Spirits be
Inuiſible, bright angels are you ſo?
Be you inuiſible to euery eye.
Saue onely theſe: Sleepe, Ile not breake your reſt,
Though you breake mine: Deare Saints adiew, adiew:
My feete part from you, but my ſoule dwels with you.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: Is he gone? ô Fortune my friend, & not fortune my foe,
I come downe to embrace thee, and kiſſe thy great toe.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Fellow Onion? Peter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Fellow Iuniper. What's the old panurgo gone? departed, coſmografied, ha?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O I, and harke Sirrah. Shall I tell him? no.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Nay, be briefe and declare, ſtand not vpon conodrums now, thou knoweſt what contagious ſpeeches I haue ſufferd for thy ſake and he ſhould come againe and inuent me here.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: He ſaies true, it was for my ſake, I will tell him.
Sirra Iuniper? and yet I will not.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: What ſayeſt thou ſweete Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: And thou hadſt ſmelt the ſent of me when I was in the tree, thou wouldeſt not haue ſaid ſo: but Sirra, The caſe is alterd with me, my heart has giuen loue a box of the eare, made him kicke vp the heeles I faith.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Sayeſt thou me ſo, wad Greeke? how haps it? how chances it.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I cannot hold it, Iuniper, haue an eye, looke, haue an eye to the doore, the old prouerb's true, I ſee: gold is but mucke. Nay Gods ſo Iuniper to the doore, an eye to the maine chance, here you ſlaue, haue an eye.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: O inexorable! ô infallible! ô infricate deuine, and ſuperficiall fortune.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay, it will be ſufficient anon, here, looke heere.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: O inſolent good lucke! How didſt thou produce th'intelligence of the gold' mynerals.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: Ile tell you that anon, heere, make ſhift, conuey, cramme.
Ile teach you how you ſhall call for garlike againe I faith.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: S'bloud what ſhall we do with all this? we ſhall nere bring it to a conſumption.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Conſumption? why weele bee moſt ſumptuouſly attir'd, man.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: By this gold, I will haue three or foure moſt ſtigmaticall ſuites preſently.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ile go in my foot-cloth, Ile turne Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: So will I.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: But what badge ſhall we giue, what culliſon?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: As for that lets vſe the infidelity and commiſeration of ſome harrot of armes, he ſhall giue vs a gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: A gudgeon? a ſcutheon thou wouldſt ſay, man.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: A ſcutcheon or a gudgeon, all is one.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well, our armes be good inough, lets looke to our legges.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Content, weele be iogging.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Rachel? we retire: garlike God boy ye.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Farewell ſweete Iaques.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Farewell ſweete Rachel, ſweet dogge adiew.

div.stage: Fnter Maximilian, Count Ferneze, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Pache.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Nay but ſweet Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Away, Ile heare no more,
Neuer was man ſo palpably abuld,
My ſonne ſo baſely marted; and my ſelfe
Am made the ſubiect of your mirth and ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Count Ferneze you tread to hard vpon my patience,
Do not perſiſt I aduiſe your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I will perſiſt, and vnto thee I ſpeake.
Thou. Maximilian thou haſt iniur'd me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Before the Lord:

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sweet ſignior.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.p: O my father.

sp.speaker: Mvx.
sp.p: Lady let your father thank your beauty.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: By gar me ſhall be hang for tella dis ſame,
Metella madamoy ſelle, ſhe tell her ſadera.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: The true Chamount ſet free, and one left here
Of no deſcent, clad barely in his name.
Sirrah boy come hither, and be ſure, you ſpeake the ſimple truth:

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O pardone moy mounſieur,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Come leaue your pardons, and directly ſay.
What villaine is the ſame that hath vſurpt,
The honor'd name and perſon of Chamount:

sp.speaker: Pac
sp.p: O Mounſieur, no point villaine, braue Cheualier, Mounſieur Gaſper.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mounſieur Gaſper, on what occaſion did they change their names, what was their policy, or their pretext.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Me canno tell, par ma foy Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My honorable Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tut tut, be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Silent? Count Ferneze, I tell thee if Amurath the great
Turke were here I would ſpeake, and he ſhould here me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So will not I.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: By my fathers hand, but thou ſhalt Count, I ſay till this inſtant, I was neuer toucht in my reputation: here me you ſhall knowe that you haue wrongd me, and I will make you acknowledge it, if I cannot my ſword ſhall.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By heauen I will not, I will ſtop mine eares,
My ſences loath the Sauiour of thy breath.
Tis poyſon to me, I ſay I will not heare.
What ſhall I know, tis you haue iniurd me,
What will you make? make me acknowledge it.
Fetch forth that Gaſper, that lewd counterfeit.
Ile make him to your face approue your wrongs.
Come on falſe ſubſtance, ſhadow to Chamont:
Had you none elſe to worke vpon but me,
Was I your fitteſt proiect? well confeſſe,
What you intended by this ſecret plot.
And by whoſe policy it was contriu'd,
Speake truth, and be intreated courteouſly,
But double with me, and reſolue to proue
The extremeſt rigor that I can inflict.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My honor'd Lord, heare me with patience,
Nor hope of fauour, not the feare of torment,
Shall ſway my tongue, from vttring of a truth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tis well, proceed then.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The morne before this battell did begin,
Wherein my Lord Chamount and I were tane,
We vow'd one mutuall fortune, good or bad,
That day ſhould be imbraced of vs both,
And vrging that might worſt ſucceede our vow,
We there concluded to exchange our names.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then Maximilian tooke you for Chamount.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: True noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tis falſe, ignoble wretch,
Twas but a complot to betray my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Count, thou lyeſt in thy boſome, Count▪

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lye?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay I beſeech you honor'd gentlemen,
Let not the vntimely ruine of your loue,
Follow theſe ſleight occurents; be aſſured
Chamounts returne will heale theſe wounds againe,
And breake the points of your too piercing thoughts.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Returne? I when? when will Chamount returne?
Heele come to fetch you, will he? I tis like,
Youl'd haue me thinke ſo, that's your policy.
No, no, yong gallant, your deuice is ſtale,
You cannot feed me with ſo vaine a hope.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord, I feede you not with a vaine hope,
I know aſſuredly he will returne,
And bring your noble ſonne along with him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I, I dare pawne my ſoule he will returne.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O impudent diriſion? open ſcorne?
Intollerable wrong? is't not inough?
That you haue plaid vpon me all this while;
But ſtill to mocke me, ſtill to ieſt at me?
Fellowes, away with him, thou ill-bred ſlaue,
That ſets no difference twixt a noble ſpirit,
And thy owne ſlauiſh humour, do not thinke
But ile take worthy vengeance on thee, wretch?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas, theſe threats are idle, like the wind,
And breed no terror in a guiltleſſe mind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, thou ſhalt want no torture, ſo reſolue, bring him away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Welcome the worſt, I ſuffer for a friend,
Your tortures will, my loue ſhall neuer end.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Alas poore gentleman, my fathers rage
Is too extreame, too ſterne and violent
O that I knew with all my ſtrongeſt powers,
How to remoue it from thy patient breaſt,
But that I cannot, yet my willing heart,
Shall miniſter in ſpight of tyranny
To thy miſfortune, ſomething there is in him,
That doth enforce this ſtrange affection,
With more then common rapture in my breaſt:
For being but Gaſper, he is ſtill as deare
To me, as when he did Chamount appeare.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: But in good ſadneſſe Signior, do you thinke Chamount will returne?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Do I ſee your face, Lady?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: I ſure, if loue haue not blinded you.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: That is a queſtion, but I will aſſure you no, I can ſee, and yet loue is in mine eye: well, the Count your father ſimply hath diſhonor'd me: and this ſteele ſhall engraue it on his burgonet.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: Nay, ſweet Signior.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Lady, I do preferre my reputation to my life,
But you ſhall rule me, come lets march.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Ile follow Signior, ô ſweet Queene of loue!
Soueraigne of all my thoughts, and thou faire fortune,
Who (more to honour my affections)
Haſt thus tranſlated Gaſper to Chamount.
Let both your flames now burne in one bright ſpeare;
And giue true light to my a ſpiring hopes,
Haſten Chamounts returne, let him affect me,
Though father, friends, and all the world reiect me.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sigh for a woman, would I fould mine armes,
Raue in my ſleepe, talke idly being awake,
Pine and looke pale, make loue-walkes in the night,
To ſteale cold comfort from a day-ſtarres eyes.
Kit, thou art a foole, wilt thou be wiſe? then lad
Renounce this boy-gods nice idolatry,
Stand not on complement, and wooing trickes,
Thou loueſt old Iaques daughter, doeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Loue her?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Come, come, I know't, be rul'd and ſhees thine owne,
Thou't ſay her father Iaques, the old begger,
Hath pawnd his word to thee, that none but thou,
Shalt be his ſonne in law.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: He has.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: He has? wilt thou beleeue him, and be made a kooke,
To waite on ſuch an antique wether cocke;
Why he is more inconſtant then the ſea,
His thoughts, Cameleon-like, change euery minute:
No Kit, worke ſoundly, ſteale the wench away,
Wed her, and bed her, and when that is done,
Then ſay to Iaques, ſhall I be your ſonne?
But come to our deuiſe, where is this gold?

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Heere Signior Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Beſtow it, bid thy hands ſhed golden drops,
Let theſe bald french crownes be vncouered,
In open ſight, to do obeyſance
To Iaques ſtaring eyes when he ſteps forth,
The needy beggar will be glad of gold.
So, now keepe thou alooſe, and as he treades
This guilded path, ſtretch out his ambling hopes,
With ſcattring more & more, & as thou go'ſt, cry Iaques, Iaques

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Tuſt, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Firſt ile play the ghoſt, Ile cal him out, Kit keep aloofe.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: But Signior Angelo. Where wil your ſelfe and Rachel ſtay for me, after the ieſt is ended?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Maſſe, that's true, at the old Priory behinde S. Foyes.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Agreed, no better place, ile meete you there.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Do good foole, do, but ile not meet you there.
Now to this geere, Iaques, Iaques, what Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who cals? whoſe there?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who cals?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Steward, he comes, he comes Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What voice is this? no body here, was I not cald? I was.
And one cride Iaques with a hollow voyce,
I was deceiu'd, no I was not deceiu'd,
See ſee, it was an Angell cald me forth,
Gold, gold, man▪ making gold, another ſtarre,
Drop they from heauen, no, no, my houſe I hope
Is haunted with a Fairy. My deere Lar,
My houſhold God, My Fairy on my knees.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My Lar doth call me, ô ſweet voyce.
Muſicall as the ſpheares, ſee, ſee, more gold.

sp.p: What Rachel, Rachel, lock my doore, looke to my houſe.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Shut faſt my doore, a golden crowne, Iaques ſhall be a king.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: To a fooles paradice that path will bring
Thee and thy houſhold Lar.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What means my father, I wonder what ſtrange humor.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Come ſweete ſoule, leaue wondring, ſtart not, twas I laid this plot to get thy father forth.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: O Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: O me no oo's, but heare, my Lord your loue,
Paulo Ferneze is returnd from warre,
Lingers at Pont Valeria, and from thence
By poſt at midnight laſt, I was coniur'd
To man you thither, ſtand not on replies,
A horſe is ſadled for you, will you go,
And I am for you, if you will ſtay, why ſo.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: O Angelo, each minute is a day till my Ferneze come, come weele away ſir.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sweet ſoule I gueſſe thy meaning by thy lookes,
At po • t Valerio thou thy loue ſhalt ſee,
But not Ferneze, Steward fare you well.
You wait for Rachel to, when can you tell?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O in what golden circle haue I dan'ſt?
Millaine theſe od'rous and enfloured fields
Are none of thine, no heres Elizium,
Heere bleſſed ghoſts do walke, this is the Court
And glorious palace where the God of gold
Shines like the ſonne, of ſparkling maieſty;
O faire fethered, my red-breſted birds,
Come flye with me, ile bring you to a quier,
Whoſe conſort being ſweetned with your ſound:
The muſique will be fuller, and each hower
Theſe eares ſhall banquet with your harmony ô, ô, ô,

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: At the old priorie, behind Saint Foyes,
That was the place of our appointment ſure:
I hope he will not make me looſe my gold,
And mock me to, perhaps they are within: Ile knock.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O God, the caſe is alterd.

sp.speaker: Angelo?
sp.p: Signior Angelo?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Angels? I where? mine Angels? wher's my gold?
Why Rachel? O thou theeuiſh Canibal,
Thou eateſt my fleſh in ſtealing of my gold.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: What gold?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What gold? Rachel call help, come forth,
Ile rip thine entrailes, but ile haue my gold:
Rachel why comes thou not? I am vndone,
Ay me ſhe ſpeakes not, thou haſt ſlaine my child.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: What is the man poſſeſt trow? this is ſtrange,
Rachel I ſee is gone with Angelo:
Well ile once againe vnto the priory,
And ſee if I can meete them.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Tis too true,
Th'aſt made away my child, how haſt my gold:
O what Hienna cald me out of dores,
The theife is gone: my gold's gone, Rachels gone,
Al's gone? ſaue I that ſpend my cries in vaine,
But ile hence too, and die or end this paine.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.l: Swonds, let me goe, hay catſo, catch him aliue,
I call, I call, boy, I come, I come ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Page hold my rapier, while I hold my freind here.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O heer's a ſweet metamorphoſis, a cupple of buzzards turn'd to a paire of peacocks.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Signior Onion, lend me thy boy to vnhang my rapier. On. Signior Iuniper for once or ſo, but troth is, you muſt inueigle, as I haue done, my Lords page here a poor folower of mine.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Hei ho, your page then ſha'not be ſuper intendent vpon me? he ſhall not be addicted? he ſhall not be incident? he ſhall not be incident? he ſhall not be incident, ſhall he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.l: O ſweet ſignior Iuniper.
Iuni Sbloud ſtand away princocks? do not aggrauate my ioy.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Nay good Maiſter. Onion.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay and he haue the heart to draw my bloud, let him come.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Ile ſlice you Onion, Ile ſlice you?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ile cleaue you Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why hold, hold, hough? what do you meane?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p:
Let him come Ingle, ſtand by boy, his allebaſter blad
cannot feare me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Why heare you ſweet ſignior, let not there be any contētion, betweene my Maiſter & you, about me, if you want a page ſir, I can helpe you to a proper ſtripling.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Canſt thou? what parentage? what anceſtry? what genealogy is he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: A french boy ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Has he his French linguiſt? has he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I, ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Then tranſport him: her's a cruſado for thee.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: You will not, imbecell my ſeruant with your beneuolence will you, hold boy their's a portmantu for thee.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Lord ſir.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Do take it boy, its three pounds ten ſhill. a portmantu.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I thanke your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.l: Sirrah Ningle: thou art a traueller, and I honour thee.
I prithee diſcourſe? cheriſh thy muſe? diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Of what ſir?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Of what thou wilt. Sbloud? hang ſorrow?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Prithy Valentine aſſoile me one thing.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Tis pitty to ſoile you ſir, your new apparell.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Maſſe thou ſaiſt true, aparel makes a man forget himſelf.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Begin, find your tongue Ningle.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now will gull theſe ganders rarely:
Gentlemen hauing in my peregrinatiō through Meſopotamia.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Speake legibly, this gam's gone, without the great mercy of God,
Heres a fine tragedy indeed. Thers a Keiſars royall.
By Gods lid, nor King nor Keiſar ſhall?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: Where? where? Finio, where be they.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Go to, ile be with you anon.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O her's the page ſignior Iuniper:

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: What ſayth monſier Onion, boy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: What ſay you ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tread out boy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Take vp, you meane ſir.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Tread out I ſay, ſo, I thanke you, is this the boy.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Aue mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Who gaue you that name.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Giue me de name, vat name:

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: He thought your name had been, we yong gentlemen, you muſt do more then his legges can do for him, beare with him ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Sirrah giue me inſtance of your carriage? youle ſerue my turne, will you?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: What? turne vpon the toe.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O ſignior no.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Page will you follow me, ile giue you good exhibition.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: By gar, ſhal not alone follow you, but ſhal leade you to.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Plaguie boy, he ſooths his humour? theſe french villaines ha pockie wits.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Here? diſarme me? take my ſemitary.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O rare, this would be a rare man, and he had a little trauell, Balthaſar, Martino, put off your ſhooes, and bid him coble them.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Freinds, friends, but pardon me for fellows, no more in occupation, no more in corporation, tis ſo pardon me, the caſe is alterd, this is law, but ile ſtand to nothing.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Fat ſo me tinke.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Well then God ſaue the dukes Maieſty, is this any harme now? ſpeake, is this any harme now.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No nor good neither, Sbloud?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Do you laugh at me? do you laugh at me? do you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I ſir, we do.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: You do indeed?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tis ſufficient, Page carry my purſe, dog me?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Gentlemen leaue him not, you ſee in what caſe he is, he is not in aduerſity, his purſe is full of money, leaue him not?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay gentle Rachel?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Away? forbeare? vngentle Angelo,
Touch not my body, with thoſe impious hands,
That like hot Irons ſeare my trembling heart,
And 〈◊〉 it hiſſe, at your diſloyalty.

Wa •
〈◊〉 your drift? to vſe Fernezes name?
Was he your fitteſt ſtale, ô wild diſhonor!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Stay noble ſir▪

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sbloud how like a puppet do you talke now?
Diſhonor? what diſhonor? come, come, foole,
Nay then I ſee y'are peeuiſh, S'heart diſhonor?
To haue you a toprieſt and marry you,
And put you in an honorable ſtate.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: To marry me? ô heauen, can it be?
That men ſhould liue with ſuch vnfeeling ſoules,
Without or touch or conſcience of religion,
Or that their warping appetites ſhould ſpoile
Thoſe honor'd formes, that the true ſeale of friendſhip
Had ſet vpon their faces.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Do you heare? what needs all this? ſay, will you haue me, or no?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Il'e haue you gone, and leaue me, if you would.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Leaue you? I was accurſt to bring you hither,
And make ſo faire an offer to a foole.
A pox vpon you, why ſhould you be coy,
What good thing haue you in you to be proud of?
Are y'any other then a beggars daughter?
Becauſe you haue beauty. O Gods light a blaſt.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: You ſcornefull baggage, I lou'd thee not ſo much, but now I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Vpon my knees, you heauenly powers, I thanke you,
That thus haue tam'd his wild affections.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: This will not do, I muſt to her againe,
Rachel, ô that thou ſawſt my heart, or didſt behold,
The place from whence that ſcalding figh euented.
Rachel, by Ieſu I loue thee as my ſoule, Rachel, ſweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What againe returnd vnto this violent paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Do but heare me, by heauen I loue you Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Pray forbeare, ô that my Lord Ferneze were but here.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Sbloud and he were, what would he do.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: This would he do baſe villaine.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: My deere Lord,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Thou monſter, euen the ſoule of trechery!
O what diſhonord title of reproch,
May my tongue ſpit in thy deſerued face?
Me thinkes my very preſence ſhould inuert,
The ſteeled organs of thoſe traytrous eyes,
To take into thy heart, and pierce it through:
Turn'ſt thou them on the ground? wretch, dig a graue,
With their ſharp points, to hide th'abhorred head;
Sweet loue, thy wrongs haue beene too violent
Since my departure from thee, I perceiue:
But now true comfort ſhall againe appeare,
And like an armed angell guard thee ſafe
From all th'aſſaults of couered villany.
Come Mounſieur, let's go, & leaue this wretch to his deſpaire.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: My noble Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: What canſt thou ſpeake to me, and not thy tongue,
Forc't with the torment of thy guilty ſoule
Breake that infected circle of thy mouth,
Like the rude clapper of a crazed bell.
I, that in thy boſome lodg'd my ſoule,
With all her traine of ſecrets, thinking them
To be as ſafe, and richly entertained,
As in a Princes court, or tower of ſtrength,
And thou to proue a traitor to my truſt,
And baſely to expoſe it, ô this world!

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: My honorable Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: The very owle, whō other birds do ſtare & wonder at,
Shall hoot at thee, and ſnakes in euery buſh
Shall deafe thine eares with their—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord, giue end vnto your paſſions.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee, I will redeeme your loſt opinion.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: My Lord beleeue him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Come, be ſarisfied, ſweet Lord you know our haſte,
Let vs to horſe, the time for my engaged returne is paſt;
Be friends againe, take him along with you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Come ſignior Angelo, hereafter proue more true.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tut Maximillian, for your honor'd ſelfe,
I am perſwaded, but no words ſhall turne
The edge of purpoſd vengeance on that wretch,
Come, bring him forth to execution.
Ile hang him for my ſonne, he ſhall not ſcape,
Had he an hundred liues: Tell me vile ſlaue,
Thinkeſt thou I loue my ſonne? is he my fleſh?
Is he my bloud, my life? and ſhall all theſe be torturd for thy
ſake, and not reueng'd? truſſe vp the villaine.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My Lord, there is no law to confirme this action.
Tis diſhonorable.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Diſhonorable? Max imillian?
It is diſhonorable in Chamount, the day of his prefixt returne is paſt, and he ſhall pay fort.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
Vſe your extreameſt vengeance, ile be glad
To ſuffer ten times more, for ſuch a friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O reſolute and peremptory wretch!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My honored Lord, let vs intreat a word.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ile heare no more, I ſay he ſhall not liue,
My ſelfe will do it. Stay, what forme is this
Stands betwixt him and me, and holds my hand.
What miracle is this? tis my owne fancy,
Carues this impreſſion in me, my ſoft nature,
That euer hath retaind ſuch fooliſh pitty,
Of the moſt abiect creatures miſery,
That it abhorres it, what a child am I
To haue a child? Ay me, my ſon, my ſon.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: O my deere loue, what is become of thee?
What vniuſt abſence layeſt thou on my breſt,
Like waights of lead, when ſwords are at my backe,
That run me through with thy vnkind flight,
My gentle diſpoſition waxeth wild,
I ſhall run frantike, ô my loue, my loue.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My gold, my gold, my life, my ſoule, my heauen,
What is become of thee? ſee, ile impart
My miſerable loſſe to my good Lord,
Let me haue ſearch my Lord, my gold is gone.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My ſonne, Chriſtophero, thinkſt it poſſible,
I euer ſhall behold his face againe.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: O father wher's my loue, were you ſo careleſſe
To let an vnthrift ſteale away your child.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I know your Lordſhip may find out my gold,
For Gods ſake pitty me, iuſtice, ſweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Now they haue yong Chamount? Chriſtophero?
Surely they neuer will reſtore my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Who would haue thought you could haue beene ſo careleſſe to looſe your onely daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Who would thinke,
That looking to my gold with ſuch hares eyes,
That euer open, I euen when thy ſleepe,
I thus ſhould looſe my gold, my noble Lord, what ſaies your
Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O my ſonne, my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: My deereſt Rachel?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My moſt hony gold.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Heare me Chriſtophero.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Nay heare me Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Heare me moſt honor'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: What rule is here?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O God that we ſhould let Chamount eſcape.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I and that Rachel, ſuch a vertuous mayd, ſhould be thus ſtolne away.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And that my gold, being ſo hid in earth, ſhould bee found out.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: O confuſion of languages, & yet no tower of Babel!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ladies, beſhrew me, if you come not fit to make a iangling conſort, will you laugh to ſee three conſtant paſſions.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Stand by, I will vrge them, ſweet Count, will you be comforted.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: It cannot be but he is handled the moſt cruelly,
That euer any noble priſoner was.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Steward, go cheere my Lord:

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Well, if Rachel tooke her flight willingly?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Sirrah, ſpeake you touching your daughters flight?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O that I could ſo ſoone forget to know the thiefe againe, that had my gold, my gold.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Is not this pure▪

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O thou baſe wretch, ile drag thee through the ſtreets.
sp.stage: Enter Balthaſar, and whiſpers with him.
sp.l: And as a monſter, make thee wondred at, how now.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Sweet Gentleman? how too vnworthily
Art thou thus tortured, braue Maximillian,
Pitty the poore youth and appeaſe my father,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: How, my ſonne returnd? O Maximillian,
Franciſco, daughters? bid him enter here.
Doſt thou not mocke me? O my deere Paulo welcome.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My Lord Chamount?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My Gaſper.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My gold Rachel? my gold?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Some body bid the begger ceaſe his noiſe.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: O ſignior Angelo, would you deceiue
Your honeſt friend, that ſimply truſted you?
Well Rachel: I am glad tho' art here againe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I faith ſhe is not for you ſteward.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I beſeech you maddam vrge your father.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I will anon? good Iaques be content.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now God a mercy fortune, and ſweet Venus,
Let Cupid do his part, and all is well.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Me thinks my heart's in heauen with this comfort.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Is this the true Italian courteſie.
Ferneze were you torturd thus in France? by my ſoules ſafety.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: My moſt noble Lord? I do beſeech your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Honored Count, wrong not your age with flexure of a knee,
I do impute it to thoſe cares and griefes,
That did torment you in your abſent ſonne.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O worthy gentlemen, I am a ſhamd
That my extreame affection to my ſonne,
Should giue my honour ſo vncur'd a maine,
But my firſt ſonne, being in Vicenza loſt.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: How in Vicenza? loſt you a ſonne there?
About what time my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O the ſame night, wherein your noble father tooke the towne.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How long's that ſince my Lord? can you remember.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tis now well nie vpon the twentith yeare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And how old was he then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot tel, betweene the yeares of three and ſoure, I take it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Had he no ſpeciall note in his attire,
Or otherwiſe, that you can call to mind.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: I cannot well remember his attire,
But I haue often heard his mother ſay:
He had about his necke a tablet,
Giuen to him by the Emperour Sigiſmund.
His Godfather, with this inſcription,
Vnder the figure of a ſiluer Globe: En minimo, mundus.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How did you call your ſonne my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Camillo Lord Chamount.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then no more my Gaſper? but Camillo,
Take notice of your father, gentlemen:
Stand not amazd? here is a tablet,
With that inſcription? found about his necke
That night, and in Vicenza by my father,
(Who being ignorant, what name he had)
Chriſtned him Gaſper, nor did I reueale,
This ſecret till this hower to any man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O happy reuelation? ô bleſt hower? ô my Camillo.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: O ſtrange my brother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Maximilion? behold how the aboundance of his ioy Drownds him in teares of gladneſſe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O my boy? forgiue thy fathers late auſterity:

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My Lord? I deliuered as much before, but your honour would not be perſwaded, I will heareafter giue more obſeruance to my viſions? I drempt of this.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I can be ſtill no longer, my good Lord,
Do a poore man ſome grace mongſt all your ioyes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why whats the matter Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I am robd, I am vndone my Lord, robd and vndone:
A heape of thirty thouſand golden crownes,
Stolne from me in one minnte, and I feare:
By her confedracy, that cals me father,
But ſhe's none of mine, therefore ſweet Lord:
Let her be tortured to confeſſe the truth.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: More wonders yet.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How Iaques is not Rachel then thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No, I diſclaime in her, I ſpit at her,
